Hilda clearly took good care of her body, and her claim that she had been walking all day was clearly an exaggeration - with how clean and pillowy her feet were, he would have assumed that she had just stepped out of the sauna.

"So, my miniature masseuse," said Hilda, idly checking her nails. They were still the perfect pigment of pink, of course. "Are you enjoying yourself down there? Thinking about applying full-time?"

Claude rolled his eyes. "Thanks, but no thanks. I'm just wondering why it smells like roses. Not that I'm complaining, of course."

"I take care of myself from head to toe!" Hilda beamed with pride as she eyed her feet from afar. She prized herself on her beauty and hygiene, after all. "I should be beautiful in every place where it counts. Oh, move up a bit too, would you?"

"Tell me-" Claude grunted as he had to stretch his arms to reach up Hilda's arch, much to her amusement and pleasure. "-just how often does that actually make any difference?"

"Hey, you'd be surprised. I've gotten some guys to run all the way to town and back on errands for me, and all I have to do is flash them some of this," Hilda wiggled her toes to demonstrate her point.

Claude quirked an eyebrow as he pushed harder in the soft surface before him. "I think you're hanging out with some strange guys, Hilda. Do me a favor and hire one of them for this next time, would ya?"

"If any of them are dumb enough to botch their next stomach flu poison, I'll be sure to keep that in mind," Hilda answered with a smirk. "Now put your shoulder into it. You've still got Leftie to do after this."

Claude groaned. This was going to be a very long ten minutes.
1411231.title: She'll Never Bring This Up Again (Maybe, Probably)

choices: Another student comes in, Hilda forces her feet into her boots to hide Claude.
Hilda wants to subjugate Claude a bit more, which he refuses.
As promised, Hilda takes Claude to see the professor.
14112312.content:
Claude worked his hands over the soft sole of what used to be his closest ally in scheming. Tragically, he would have to look into getting a new person to fill that position, as Hilda proved to be a traitor to the Alliance.

The rest of the Golden Deer were either a bit too straight laced like Leonie or unreliable loud and unsubtle like Raphael. There was Lysithea, and he was pretty sure she would treat him worse at this size given his penchant for mocking her for her age.

The tiny noble pressed his fists into Hilda’s heel, earning an exaggerated moan of pleasure. He shuddered. Despite the fact that he knew she did it to emasculate him further, it made him feel humiliated all the same. The two knew just how to push each other’s buttons. If he were totally honest, he would have messed with her if he found her small as well.

“Bet you’re getting a real big kick out of this,” Claude said, gliding his hands over the slight wrinkles on the giantess’ sole. “Seeing the future Alliance Leader massaging your feet like a handmaiden.”

“Okay, Lorenz,” Hilda said, mocking his tone while getting right back at Claude’s earlier comment. “After this, I want you to get right in between my toes.”

Claude stared up at the digits that were far out of reach. Her toes clenched in anticipation. While her sole was just a way of skin, there was something even more degrading about the idea of squeezing himself between her toes. “Yeah, that’s not happening.”

“We had a deal, Claude. You can’t reneg,” Hilda said. She put on a haughty voice. “The Leicester Alliance was founded on trade agreements and treaties built on the word of a noble.”

“I’ve met your brother, you know,” Claude said, punching Hilda’s heel. “He does not sound like that.”

“He totally does,” she shot back. “And quit changing the subject. My piggies are still waiting.”

“Oh, dear goddess, you just called them piggies,” he grumbled under his breath. He brought his hands to his face in annoyance, only to pull them away once he remembered where they’ve been. He peered over the side of her heel. “You can see I can’t reach them, right?”

“Are you suggesting I have big feet? That’s a very rude thing to say to a woman.” Hilda puffed her cheeks and crossed her arms. “Fine. If you really need the help.”

Claude only had a second to react as Hilda dropped her foot right down on top of him. She dragged it across the surface of the chair, gripping him in the space between the ball of her foot and toes. She flexed her digits, making sure to force the tiny noble in the slight gap between her largest toes.

His arms were pinned at his sides, now rendered completely helpless to Hilda’s whims. Even her toes were enough to completely dominate him, a reality he didn’t want to reflect on but was forced to recognize. While there was nothing malicious from the way she manhandled him, it was harrowing all the same.

The smell of roses was still there, but that didn’t really make things any better, just… less worse. His mind was set on what could have been worse rather than what he was taking for granted.

Hilda crossed her legs, lifting Claude high into the air as she shifted position. She giggled as she felt his squirming body tickle against her sensitive skin. “Just like that, Claude. Put your whole body into it.”

He immediately stopped writhing, as if it would do anything other than confirm that Hilda’s mind games were working.

“Alright, Hilda, you’ve had you’re fun,” Claude said. “You can take me to the professor now.”

“I’ll think about it. But you still have my other foot, ya know.”

Hilda absentmindedly rolling her ankle. All this did was make Claude feel a bit sick as the constant motion reminded him of the time he was tied to horse as child. Though, this was certainly worse. Even the anger he felt when everyone laughed at him was nothing compared to Hilda’s taunting combined with being treated like a plaything.

He just hoped Hilda wasn’t feeling playful anymore.
14112312.title: Toeing the Line

choices: "...let's take a break." Hilda leaves to retrieve Claude. He's fine but pissed.
"...let's take a break." Hilda leaves to retrieve Claude. He's seriously hurt.
"...is your foot okay? Let me take a look." Leonie ends up discovering Claude.
141123121.content:
"Hilda!" A feminine, somewhat accusing voice rang out from the classroom entrance. "There you are!"

Claude yelped in alarm as Hilda suddenly snagged him in a vice-like grip with her toes. "Hilda! What are youMMPPPH!"

Thinking quickly, Hilda quickly shoved her feet- and tiny house leader- into her boots just as Leonie entered. "Leonie! How are you? Did you change your mind about your good-luck charm? There's lots of pretty things I can..."

"We're both on weeding duty this week," Leonie said firmly. "I've been looking for you everywhere. Come on, let's get it over with before it gets too hot outside."

Hilda frowned. "I thought I was working with Raphael."

"The professor had me switch places with Raphael," Leonie folded her arms and gave Hilda an accusing glare. "You know... after you tricked him."

"I didn't trick him!" Hilda defended herself. "I just wasn't feeling well, so he volunteered to do my share of the work. You know Raphael's a sweetheart like that..."

"Well I hope you don't expect to pull that on me," Leonie's glare grew in intensity. "I had to postpone a training session with Captain Jeralt because of you. You'll do your fair share of the work or you'll regret it."

"Alright, fine," Hilda rolled her eyes. "Go ahead, I'll meet you out there."

Leonie didn't move. "No, I think we'll go together."

Hilda frowned nervously and glanced down at her boot, where she could feel the tiny Claude struggling. While him being in her boot trapped between her toes was hilarious, actually walking around and risking hurting him would take it too far. That said, letting Leonie see him wasn't an option either. As irritable as she was, who knew how she'd react to Claude's situation or how Hilda had been taking advantage of it?

"Leonie? Can you wait outside for a sec?"

Leonie's eyes narrowed. "Why?"

"Never mind," Hilda sighed. With great reluctance, she rose from her chair, putting as much weight on her non-beClauded foot as possible. When it inevitably came time to take the next step, she set her foot down as gently as possible, wincing as Claude's struggles intensified.

The fact that it tickled was doing neither of them any favors.

"Hilda, I just said I wasn't falling for your tricks!" Leonie snapped. "Stop acting like your foot's injured. I know you were fine this morning."

"Um... heh... sorry... you got me," Hilda chucked nervously, walking normally while silently apologizing to Claude and praying to the goddess she only occasionally believed in that he'd be alright.

Satisfied that Hilda would stop messing around and follow her, Leonie turned her gaze to the floor next to the desk and frowned in disgust. "Who the hell left their socks lying around in the classroom?"

"I have no idea," Hilda lied effortlessly as she joined Leonie outside.

---

"Hey, kid, thanks for getting me out of training with Pinelli today," Jeralt raised his teacup to his daughter in a brief cheer. "It's crappy to go back on my word, but sometimes her hero worship just gets to be too much." He sipped his tea. "Get enough of that from Alois," he muttered.

"It's fine," Byleth nodded as she sipped her own cup. Having just received her class's assignment for the month from Rhea and Seteth, Byleth stopped by her father's office for a visit. It was one of the precious few moments of alone time they'd had since their new life at the monastery began. "I needed to switch some chore pairings around anyway. One of my students is a helpful but dim sort, and some of the craftier nobles I've been saddled with tend to take advantage of him. Leonie seemed less likely to put up with that."

Jeralt scoffed. "Remind me why you picked that house again?"

"Edelgard and Dimitri tried to recruit me to their armies immediately after meeting me. Left a bad taste in my mouth," Byleth shrugged. "Claude has his own issues, but once he's learned some humility, I think he'll turn out just fine..."

---

"Hilda, when I get out of this, I'm going to have you tied to a horse," Claude grunted as he ineffectually punched her big toe. "Maybe a wyvern."

Claude had no idea what was going on outside the boot. He heard what sounded like Leonie talking to Hilda, but their voices were too muffled by the thick leather wall for him to understand what they were saying. Things took a turn for the worse when Hilda actually started walking. His arms were strong enough from years of using a bow that he was able to hang onto her toes and not slip beneath her foot. As long as he could avoid slipping beneath her foot, his body would survive, even if his dignity was a lost cause.

At least, that was the plan before Hilda started to sweat.

The first warning sign was the inside of the boot growing hotter. "Crap, she must be outside," Claude realized. Then, as Hilda's feet began to bake sockless in their boots in the harsh summer sun, sweat began to run down them, coating the shrunken archer in the saltiest, most disgusting waterfall imaginable. The rose-like scent Hilda took pride in was soon replaced with a more natural stink of foot sweat, and in short order, being in close proximity to her giant foot was every bit as disgusting as he'd initially feared it would be.

To make things worse, the sweat was making him lose his grip. And whatever Hilda was up to, she was constantly in motion. Finally, his arms gave out and he slipped beneath Hilda's sweaty sole. Claude closed his eyes tightly and curled into a ball, fearing his arms or legs would be crushed under Hilda's weight if he continued to struggle.

All he could hope for at this point was for the giant pinkette to feel his shift in position and deign to release him.

---

Leonie frowned, occasionally checking to make sure Hilda was actually working as she did her own share of the work. In spite of being called out earlier, Hilda was still visibly favoring one of her feet over the other. Oddly, however, she wasn't complaining about it like Leonie would expect her to.

Is she actually hurt?

If so, her sympathy for Hilda was limited. Her folks had taught her the story of the boy who cried wolf for a reason, after all. But if Hilda was, in fact, injured, someone needed to look at it before it got worse. Not only would she be a liability in battle otherwise, but for all of Hilda's faults, she was still Leonie's friend. Somehow.

At the very least, she had been doing her half of the work diligently enough so far that they could afford a quick break.

"Hey, Hilda..."
141123121.title: Taskmistress Leonie

choices: Leonie believes Hilda, taking her up the offer.
Leonie Believes Claude, confiscating him and taking him to the professor.
Leonie still doesn't know who to believe. She storms off in frustration.
1411231213.content:
"Hey, Hilda..." Leonie began, standing up from her squatted position. "Is your foot okay? Let me take a look."

"I'm fiiiiiine," Hilda dismissed unconvincingly, waving her arm. "Just me being dramatic, as usual."

Leonie scowled. "This isn't like you, Hilda. I expected you to milk your injury for all it's worth."

Hilda shrugged, balancing on the one Claude-less foot. "I thought I'd just grin and bear it before I went to see Professor Casagranda for help. It's nothing major."

Sighing, Leonie stooped down to Hilda's feet. "If it's nothing major, I'm sure I can help."

"N-no, really it's fine!"

Normally, Leonie would leave it at that. However, a previous run in with Lorenz treating her injured foot left her wanting to pay it forward. That, and the feact that she should've taken Hilda's pain seriously in the first place weighted on her. She wasn't going to take no for an answer. Thankfully, she still had the handkerchief Lorenz gave her.

"Here, just let me," Leonie began, grabbing Hilda by the ankle and forcing Hilda to sit on the grass.

"H-hey, stop!" the pinkette protested. "I'm fine, really."

Leonie didn't listen, starting to force off the knee high boot from her friend. It didn't take her long to realize that Hilda wasn't wearing any socks. "Wait a second, those socks in the classroom. Hilda, gross!"

"I wanted to put them back on, but you wouldn't let me do it," Hilda protested, gripping the boot to keep it on. "I blame you if my feet get blisters."

"You should've just told me."

"I don't like people seeing my feet," HIlda excused, pulling her legs away. "I'm self conscious about them."

"What!? Why?"

"Um... I have stubby toes?"

Leonie rolled her eyes, finally slipping the boot off Hilda's ankle. She studied the foot, expecting to find a gash somewhere on her friend's foot. Instead, she found a shrunken Claude plastered to Hilda's pink sole and gasping for air.

"H-hey?" he greeted, staring up at the wide eyes of his classmate. As cool of a demeanor he tried to keep at all the times. Now wasn't really the best time.

Once the shock wore off, her confused expression firmed into one with furrowed eyebrows and lip curled. "What in the Goddess' name is going on?"

Hilda racked her brain, thinking of anything that would make it look like she wasn't torturing Claude. The only thing she could think of was her previous conversation with him just before the boots incident. She just hoped it was convincing.

"Okay, Leonie, you caught us," Hilda began, peeling the shrunken house leader off her sole and depositing him on her palm. She let out her most convincing fake sigh. "Claude loves feet."

Leonie's scowl only got deeper.

"What!? N-no I don't," he protested. "She's lying."

Considering Claude and Hilda were about the least earnest students in the school, Leonie didn't know who to believe. She was just far too confused to even process what what was going on. "Uh..."

"He's super, I mean suuuuuper embarrassed about it," Hilda continued. "Why do you think he shrunk himself? It makes him easy to hide and keep secret."

"But your boots?" the disgust clear in the redhead's voice.

"Oh, he loves it," Hilda dismissed with another wave. She quickly doubled down. "Sometimes he'd spend the night in them and use my socks as a blanket. It's cute in its own weird way."

Leonie looked down to Claude, who seemed just upset. "Seriously?"

"No way!" He protested. "I screwed up by adding magic to my stomach flu poison. Hilda found me and turned me into her personal foot masseuse before you came in."

"Since when have you even opened a spell book?" Hilda asked, throwing a wrench into the shrunken noble's truth. "It's alright, Claude. Leonie won't judge, right?"

"I still have no idea what's going on."

"How about this?" Hilda began, tripling down on her own lie. "Claude can give one of his famous footrubs in exchange for keeping quiet about this whole kink thing. Trust me, Leonie, they're the absolute best."

Hilda clamped her hand around Claude to avoid his counterpoints.

Leonie, meanwhile, was still trying to decipher the truth from the two. Neither of their stories really added up, but from the expectant looks from both of her classmates, Leonie knew she had to pick her truth.
1411231213.title: Hilda's Gambit

choices: Claude wakes up still in HIlda's bra as she goes through her day.
Claude wakes in Hilda's room. She's got more fun with him planned.
Claude wakes up and realizes he's not alone with Hilda.
1411232.content:
“I’ll put you somewhere out of the way,” Hilda answered brightly. “Somewhere no one else can eeeeever find you.”

At this point, Claude was beginning to welcome public humiliation. It seemed miles better than whatever was causing Hilda’s smile to widen. He struggled against her fingertips. “C’mon this isn’t funny. The others are gonna notice I’m gone.”

Hilda ignored his protests, instead using her free hand to remove the top buttons from her shirt. “I’ll just say you went back home for Alliance Leader duties again. That’ll buy me about a week.”

The tiny house leader was a bit put off by how quickly she came up with that. It was even more unsettling to hear just how long she planned to keep him hidden. All he could do to fight back now was to keep struggling. However, her pillar-like fingers continued to manhandle him, slowly bringing him down to her exposed cleavage.

“Whoa, Hilda! This is a bit forward, isn’t it?” He said, trying to keep his cool demeanor.

“Gotta keep you safe, Mr. House Leader,” Hilda said with a wink before stuffing him in between her breasts. "Don't wanna risk losing you during my well-earned nap."

“Drop the act, Hilda,” Claude said, his head, comically poking out from her cleavage. “You have no intention of helping me.”

“Quiet, you,” she shot back, pushing him down the gorge with the tip of her finger. With a tight smile on her lips, she buttoned her shirt and leaned back against her seat. “I’m trying to sleep.”

This is going to be great, she thought, her mind racing with all the things she could do with Claude once her nap was over.

While Hilda was getting into her nap, Claude clawed at the massive walls that threatened to entomb him. Unfortunately, it seemed that everything he did only made things worse. He was mashed between his friend’s generous assets. While the two occasionally flirted, he never expected her to be this aggressive. All he could feel at the moment was the pain and the lingering scent of perfume.

He could have sworn that he was sinking deeper into the gorge. He was beginning to worry that he would be lost here forever. It wouldn’t surprise him at all to see her forget about him entirely. Though, he wasn’t particularly sure if it was any better than getting her full undivided attention.

Eventually, the giant sloth’s breaths began to slow down, signaling to the tiny noble that he was stuck here until Hilda woke up.

“This… is not as bad as I thought it’d be,” Claude remarked. “Sure it’s stuffy, and reeks of perfume, but it could’ve been worse. She could’ve thrown me in her boot, or dropped me on the seat of her chair.”

He shuddered at the thought.

“It’s… actually kind of comfortable,” he said unconvincingly. “Maybe she’d let me out if it looks like I’m enjoying myself down here. Though, I don’t want to give her the wrong idea. As hot as this situation sounds in theory, I don’t want her thinking I’m too into this.”

He rested his head against the side of Hilda’s left breast, figuring he could catch some sleep as well.

When he woke back up…

choices: Hilda is jogging to Professor Byleth's room - she hopes they'll know a cure.
Hilda is shopping in town. She’s looking for a container to keep Claude in.
Hilda is heading to her room. She thought Tiny Claude must have been a dream.
14112321.content:
Claude slowly awoke to the sensation of malleable warmth around him. He didn’t recall his dorm bed being so soft and welcoming, and yet-

The shrewd boy’s brain was back to firing on all cylinders as he realized his surreal predicament. The awful ache in his neck eschewed any need for pinching himself to see if he was still dreaming - he was back in reality, and that reality was being awkardly sandwiched between Hilda’s breasts.

The leader of the Golden Deer considered his predicament. Any prior attempt to wriggle free had just forced him to sink further down into the depths of the cleavage, so another ‘prison break’ might just send him falling out entirely. Examining his surroundings (or what little he could, since only the barest amount of light was poking into the bra after Hilda had buttoned up her shirt) he noticed that there was the slightest sway of motion.

“Wait a sec... Hilda, are you awake?!” Claude called out. Given that there was no response, he was either too small to hear or she was simply ignoring him. Either outcome seemed likely at this point. “Come on, let me out! I don’t want to smell like your girly perfume for the rest of my life!” Claude idly kicked into the flesh around him to try and garner some attention, but once more, Hilda gave no reaction.

With a frustrated sigh, Claude crossed his arms and slumped back into whatever amounted to a comfortable posture in their very unique circumstances. At this size, he could faintly hear the rhythmic thumps of her heartbeat through the skin around him. Worried as he was about Hilda taking her newfound leverage too far or potentially forgetting him entirely, he had to admit that this would make for one hell of a tale... if he ever chose to share it, of course.

“‘Hey, Teach,’” Claude said to himself. “‘Sorry I’ve missed so many seminars, I’ve been living in Hilda’s bra for the past week. I’m now the leader of the Bralliance. It’s a bountiful land known for its large hills-’”

The Bralliance was under attack as Hilda put a jump in her step, briefly smothering its leader for a moment and cutting off his improvised comedy routine.

Damn it, Hilda, what are you up to...?!
14112321.title: Another Beautiful Morning in the Bralliance

choices: Hilda puts the necklace on and shows it off to her fellow students.
Hilda slips the necklace under her shirt. The lid comes loose, and Claude slips.
Hilda gifts the necklace to someone else.
141123212.content:
(Reference to Hilda and Raphael's C Support. No real spoilers.)

Claude heard a lively yet muffled band in the distance, and it told him all he needed to know about where his giant captor was. There was the same band of musicians playing in the marketplace of the town just outside the monastery. The song playing reminded him of a time where he dragged a girl to dance to the tune in a burst of spontaneity. All he could do now was hope Hilda wouldn’t do the same as that would most certainly beat him into a pulp.

“So she’s out shopping,” he said under his breath. “Not surprised.”

Hilda floated around the stands, looking for anything cute that would catch her eye. She often did this to find supplies and materials for her handmade crafts and jewelry. However, she wasn’t just browsing as she was looking for something specific.

She recalled an earlier conversation she had with Raphael about what constituted a cute necklace for his little sister. While he insisted on something made of animal bones and wood, she had suggested placing a small flower into a crystal bottle and sealed with resin. Though, Raphael seemed to run off once she mentioned the type of flower that would be cute enough. Oh well, at least she could pick up a bottle for him.

Arriving at the usual artisan hut, Hilda eyed the basket of bottles before plucking a bottle small enough to house a flower and fit comfortably on a necklace.

Then she felt a tickle down her shirt. A stroke of genius hit her as she decided to instead grab two of the bottles. INstead of a pretty and rare flower, Claude would have to do.

After paying the merchant, she rushed down the path towards the monastery, excited to begin her next project. There was a slight bounce in her step, which jostled around her shrunken friend between her breasts. She would let him out soon enough, but for now, she could enjoy the tickling sensation as Claude struggled between her boobs.

Entering her room, Hilda dropped down onto her chair and set her supplies onto the desk. Her chest bounced, and Claude’s wiggles intensified, earning an amused giggle from the pink haired titan. She unbuttoned her shirt, finding his hand sticking out and grasping for freedom. She pinched the exposed limb and dragged him out.

The tiny house leader gasped for air, clearly making a big show of it that Hilda really didn’t appreciate. She dangled him by the cape, staring him straight in the eyes. “Don’t be so dramatic. I bet you enjoyed it.”

“I could’ve died,” he said, feigning concern.

“What a way to go, huh?” she asked. “I’m sure there’s a ton of boys that would kill to switch places with you.”

Before Claude could hit back with a snarky comment, Hilda began lowering him to the opening of the bottle. He caught on, fighting against her grip to no avail. He even tried to rip off his cape, yet it did nothing as Hilda’s pillar like finger forced him into the opening. He barely fit as the giantess practically forced him in and nearly bruising his shoulders.

“W-wait, Hilda, just what are you doing?” He asked, banging his fist against the crystal wall.

“Isn’t it obvious?” She asked, forcing a needle through a tiny cork. “I’m making you into the cutest li’l necklace.”

She kept stabbing holes through the cork, making sure they were big enough to let air in. The last thing she wanted was for her adorable little accessory to suffocate while she was wearing it. That would not be cute. Once satisfied, she grabbed a thin gold chain from her jewelry box and slipped it through one of the holes in the side of the lid. Smiling, she pushed it down on top of the opening and sealed it tight, trapping Claude and cementing his new role as a piece of jewelry for the spoiled noble.

Hilda lifted the necklace and its brand new charm up to her face, blowing a kiss to its tiny captive.

“Alright, Hilda, you can let me out,” Claude said. “This stopped being funny a while ago.”

His protests were ignored as she closed her hand around the bottle.

choices: Hilda goes to town on the opposing houses.

1421.content:
(Set during the Chapter 7 mission).

Lances axes and swords crossed on the battlefield, creating a large spectacle for the onlookers at the famed Battle of Eagle and Lion. So far, it was living up to the name as the students from the Black Eagle and Blue Lion houses clashed. The Golden Deer were notably absent.

“Gotta say, Teach,” Claude began, pausing for a moment to watch Ingrid lunge at Ferdinand with a lance. “This scheme of ours is probably the best one yet.”

Lorenz scoffed. “It better be. I see no tactical benefit to keeping the rest of us out of the know.”

Claude twirled an arrow between his fingers. “Tactical benefit? None whatsoever. But it’s gonna be a hell of a surprise.”

Meanwhile, over with the Black Eagles, Edelgard watched from her perch. “Hubert, doesn’t it seem odd to you that Claude and Professor Byleth haven’t entered the battle yet?”

“I agree,” he said, squinting to get a better look at the group of Deer across the battlefield. “They are up to something. Shall we divert our troops?”

“Good idea,” Edelgard said. “We should intercept them before they can execute whatever scheme they have.”

It didn’t take long before the rest of the Black Eagle squad began to focus their attention to cornering the Golden Deer, cutting through the field and rushing towards the group on the other side of the river.

“Well,” Claude began, watching a small army of encroaching soldiers come closer. “Looks like now’s as good as time as any.”

“Agreed,” Byleth agreed. The professor turned to a pair of students. “Hilda, Lysithea, are you ready?”

“Ab. So. Lutely!” Hilda chirped. “This is gonna be fun.”

“Just leave it to me,” Lysithea said back, her hands glowing with energy.

Leonie turned to Ignatz. “I’m scared to find out what could possibly get Hilda this excited.”

“I trust the professor’s judgement,” the archer said quietly. “If it’s approved by him, then surely it can’t be that bad.”

Little did he know, that it was that bad. Hilda stepped forward, surprisingly unarmed. She stretched her arms behind her back, and then swung them, limbering up for her part of the plan.

"Send in the tactical Hilda!" Claude yelled, putting a weighty bass in his voice.

“On three,” Byleth instructed. “One. Two.”

“Three!” Lysithea and Hilda finished, blinding the others with a bright flash of light.

The battlefield crashed into a halt as a blinding light covered the entirety of Gronder Field. Then came a massive shadow, blocking the light over the Blue Lion and Black Eagle teams.

“Ohohoho! This is AWESOME!”

As it turned out, the Golden Deer’s latest scheme was to warp a giant Hilda right into the center of the action. The pink haired giantess giggled as she looked at her tiny schoolmates scrambling away from her massive boots. She had to have been taller than the monastery’s tallest towers, a fact that she relished as she raised her boot and brought it down, sending an earthquake and knocking over the grounded units.

“This is bad,” Ignatz said meekly.

“Relax, Iggy,” Claude reassured, clapping the thinner boy on the back. “She’s on our side. You should be worried about the other houses.”

The reactions across the other houses were mixed to say the least.

“Sylvain, quit gawking,” Ingrid snapped, hitting the back of his head with the pole of her lance.

“Everyone else is doing it!” He rubbed at the sore spot.

“Not everyone’s staring up her skirt!”

“I can’t help it. It’s all I can see!”

Meanwhile, Bernadetta on the central hit trembled behind her ballista. “Uh, Edelgard, c-can I retreat now!?”

“Not yet!” The Black Eagle commander yelled. “It’s still a valuable position. Just fire at her and take her down. Everyone, work together to take Hilda down.”
1421.title: Tactical Hilda Strike

choices: Hubert manages to replicate the spell, and grows a Black Eagle to fight Hilda.
The Knights of Seiros are called in to subdue Hilda. It goes poorly.
Now thoroughly bored, Hilda turns her attention to her own classmates.
14211.content:
"Tremble, puny ants!" Hilda cackled. "Tremble before the might of Hilda!"

She punctuated this with another stomp, sending most of the ground units fleeing towards their respective bases. The exception was one lone blue and orange dot, which remained perfectly still right next to Hilda's other foot. The giantess frowned in curiosity. Was someone really planning to face her alone? She knelt down, trying to get a better look at the brave, foolish soul who...

Oh. It was Sylvain. He was looking up her skirt.

"Really, Sylvain?"

Sylvain's reply was a collection of barely coherent syllables. His nose then started bleeding. Rolling her eyes, Hilda stooped down to one knee and brought her thumb and middle finger down to the ground next to him. Piecing together what she was about to do, Sylvain snapped out of his perverted stupor and tried to run, but was too late as Hilda flicked her finger, sending the perverted knight in training hurtling through the air towards the Blue Lions home base.

On the plus side, Hilda could now probably get Sylvain to do her chores for her for the rest of the year. Once he got out of the infirmary, at least.

Meanwhile, in the hills surrounding the Black Eagles' base, Bernadetta had the sights of her ballista trained on Hilda, and was trembling with significantly more fear than usual.

"Bernadetta, she's in range!" Edelgard yelled from the nearby fortress. "Take the shot!"

"B-but one shot won't take her down!" Bernadetta tried to argue. "It... it'll take time to load another arrow, and by the time I do she'll be over here! And she'll be mad!"

"Lady Edelgard GAVE you an ORDER!" Hubert growled menacingly.

With a pitiful, terrified squeak, Bernadetta closed her eyes tightly and took the shot. The arrow sailed through the air before embedding itself into Hilda's rear.

"OW!" Hilda flinched. "What was that?!" She looked around before finding the splinter sized arrow sticking out of her skirt and pulling it out.

"That was my nicest skirt! Who did this?!"

Hilda's eyes scanned the battlefield before noticing a lone ballista in Black Eagles territory. Squinting, she recognized the frail, purple haired girl from Black Eagle House that almost never left her room. Bern... something. Smiling, she slowly stalked towards her.

"Aw... a ballista... isn't that cute..." she cooed, before her face broke into a wide grin and she raised her foot ominously over it.

"...BUT IT'S WRONG!"

Bernadetta shrieked and abandoned the ballista seconds before Hilda's boot came crashing down on it, instantly reducing it to scrap and creating a shockwave that sent the poor archer half-running, half-tumbling down the hill.

"EDELGARDI'MRETREATINGPLEASEDON'THATEMEBYE!"

"Cowardice," Hubert muttered.

"She was right about not taking the shot," Edelgard looked towards Bernadetta's retreating form with concern before turning to glare at Hubert. "We should have listened to her."

"If we are to survive what is to come, the loyalty of your subjects must be absolute, Lady Edelgard,"

"I... I know..." Edelgard looked away with a frown.

The earth then shook violently as Hilda sat down on a nearby hill, cheerfully humming to herself as she began to pick ballista parts out of the treads of her boot and deliberately flick them towards Edelgard's fortress.

"Have you figured out what spell the Golden Deer used on her?" Edelgard asked her chief mage and adviser. "Any chance of reverse engineering it? It may be the only way we can salvage this battle."

"I should be able to replicate it soon," Hubert nodded before frowning at something in the distance. "The Blue Lions are approaching."

"Of course they are..." Edelgard muttered.

---

"Move in, fellow Lions!" Dimitri ordered. "We shall take the Black Eagles' fort while they are distracted and carry the day!"

"This is a stupid idea, Dimitri," Felix growled. "We should be more worried about THAT." He gestured towards Hilda, who had finished cleaning her boot and was about to resume her rampage.

"Let Edelgard be taken in by the Golden Deer's trickery and illusions," Dimitri scoffed. "While they are distracted, we will descend on them both!"

"Illusion?!" Felix slapped his forehead in frustration. "Sylvain seemed pretty sure it was real. The Black Eagles' archer DEFINITELY thought it was real. Illusions don't destroy ballistas, Dimitri!"

"Sylvain's judgment is always clouded by members of the fairer sex," Dimitri reminded his rebellious classmate. "And from what I hear, that archer is afraid of her own shadow. Enough talk! CHARGE!"

Felix rolled his eyes as the rest of the Blue Lions heedlessly followed Dimitri into the fray. "Idiots..."

---

"Wow," Claude grinned as he watched Hilda lay waste to the battlefield. "This is going even better than I thought!"

"I'm surprised the other two houses aren't teaming up to stop her," Lysithea mused from her spot under a shady tree, laying against it to relax as she recovered from the intense magic she performed earlier. "I mean, it wouldn't have helped, but I at least expected them to make the attempt."

"I left a few anonymous notes on the bulletin boards around the monastery," Claude winked to the mage. "Petty house insults attributed to the other one. Stoked some rivalries so there was no way Edelgard and Dimitri would cooperate. It's all in good fun."

"Claude, I can't know about that," Byleth warned sternly.

"Sorry, Teach!" Claude waved his hand apologetically. "Just speaking metaphorically! You heard nothing!"

"Wait a moment," Lorenz frowned. "How is Claude's subterfuge not allowed, and yet this..." he gestured in the distance towards Hilda as she started rooting through the Black Eagles fortress like a dollhouse in order to grab Edelgard. "Is perfectly acceptable?"

"This is a completely valid exercise of Lysithea's magical abilities," Byleth explained. "One she's getting extra credit for, incidentally."

Lysithea grinned contentedly as she continued to watch the battle.

"Um... professor?" a timid voice spoke up. Byleth turned and smiled gently to their newest recruit, who the Golden Deer had heroically saved from heretics the past month.

"Yes, Flayn? What is it?"

"My brother is flying towards us," Flayn pointed in the distance. "And he does not look happy."

Byleth followed Flayn's finger. True to her words, Seteth was approaching them on his wyvern, and his scowl was more pronounced than usual.

"Professor, what IS this?!" Seteth demanded. "Lady Rhea is most upset! This unnatural display is not in keeping with the spirit of the Battle of Eagle and Lion!"

"Well, seeing as we're neither Eagles nor Lions, I don't see the problem," Byleth noted.

"Excuse me?" Seteth narrowed his eyes.

"This academy has three houses, Seteth," Byleth reminded him. "Whenever we have these events, the Golden Deer House feels like an afterthought. What's next? Are you going to forget to paint Claude in the house leader portrait and haphazardly put him in upside down at the last minute? My class is constantly feeling marginalized, and as their professor, I have to advocate for them."

"B...be that as it may, this is still unacceptable! The Golden Deer are hereby disqualified!" This was met with an uproar, as even the students who weren't on board with Hilda being a giantess protested their house's disqualification.

"Very well," Byleth sighed as he walked towards the giant warhorn he and Claude had set up on top of their fort the night before.

"Hilda," Byleth spoke through it. "It's over. We're disqualified. Come on back."

In the distance, Hilda ignored him and chased the fleeing Blue Lion army, with Edelgard struggling in her hand.

"Hilda? HILDA!"

"Can't talk, professor! Busy having fun!" Hilda called back distractedly as she reached into the crowd and snatched Dimitri.

"Welp," Byleth backed off from the war horn. "She's gone mad with power. I warned you, Claude. That's stable cleaning duty for a month."

"Damn it, Hilda," Claude muttered.

"If you expected her to go mad with power," Seteth growled, "then why did you approve this?!"

"Learning experience," Byleth shrugged.

Meanwhile, Hilda had Dimitri and Edelgard in each hand, and was now roughly mashing their faces together as the pair screamed in terror and disgust.

"NOW KIIIIIISSSSSSSS!"

"We will discuss this later," Seteth threatened Byleth as he took back to the skies in his wyvern, planning to summon the knights.

choices: Hubert sends another giant into battle
Lysithea sends Flayn into the fray
1421112.content:
"I never knew Petra had such a right hook." Byleth commented as he watched the new giantess deck Hilda across the face. Truthfully he never expected any of the other houses to replicate Lysithea's work, but they had and now they're were to giants on the battlefield.

"For someone who doesn't want to be on the front lines, Hilda seems fair amount of combat ability." Ignatz added. For the longest time all he'd seen Hilda do is complain about being on the front lines and yet she seemed to accel there. Why try to run away from what you're skilled at?

"I can't believe the Black Eagle house managed to recreate my spell." Lysithea grumbled. Hubert must've been the one to do it too. That guy always gave her the creeps when she saw him and now he'd stolen her thunder. A part of her hoped Hilda would accidently crush him.

"Maybe we should put a stop to this?" Flayn suggested.

Claude smiled. "You volunteering?"

"Over my dead body!" Seteth growled.

"Brother please?" Flayn tried to calm the angry man down.

:Flayn's right though. We do need t put a stop to this before those two tear the whole area apart." Byleth said. "Lysithea? Can't you shrink them both back down?"

The snow haired girl shook her head. "I need them weakened first. Right now they're releasing too much power and adrenaline to stop now."

14211122.title: Rise of not Daenerys ;)

choices: Edelgard and Petra do as instructed.
142111223.content:
"Woah. Didn't see that coming?" Claude commented whilst rubbing the back of his head.

"What? A giant Edelgard or the fact that both our heavy hitters lost?" Byleth asked.

"All of the above."

The situation had not improved in the slightest. Giants still dominated the battlefield only this time it was the Black Eagles' giants that did.

"The only silver lining here is that Hilda was taken down. But with Ingrid also out of commission, there's no one left to drain their battle auras" Lysithea explained.

"Great." Ignatz sighed sarcastically. "Now what are we going to do?"

"That's what I'd like to know." Seteth chimed. "In case you've forgotten, Lady Rhea wanted this resolved as soon as possible. After seeing four giants on the battlefield I believe her patience may be at it's end."

"Like I said before, we need to whittle down their battle auras before I can shrink them."

Silence reigned as the Golden Deer thought up a plan. Hilda was down so that was good. Leonie wasn't an option. Lysithea wasn't viable either as she was needed to shrink the giants. Marianne was just a no. That only left one option. One green haired option. Seteth must've sensed what the group was thinking because stood between them and his sister protectively.

"It seems our last hope is..."

"No!" Seteth stated.

"Seteth…"

"I said No!"

"But..."

"I'll not allow you to turn Flayn into a walking weapon!" Seteth growled.

Seeing as Seteth wasn't going to relent and Flayn was indecisive, Byleth took the reigns. "Look Seteth. I understand how you feel, but don't forget that the officer academy's purpose is to train warriors as much as it is to educate. Right now on the battlefield are two giants that could cause more harm than good like Hilda if left to their own devices. Flayn is our last hope. If she doesn't go then things will only get worse."

"I... I understand, but I still can't agree to this course of action."

Seteth seemed resolved in his stance until he felt a gentle hand on his shoulder. He turned to see it was Flayn giving him a look of burning determination. It was a look he'd rarely scene and one that filled him equal parts worry and pride. "Brother... Let me do this."

"Flayn…?"

The greenette tightened her grip. "I know you're scared. I'm scared too. But... I have to do this, I'm the only one who can!"

Seteth looked into Flayn's eyes, then back to the giants, and back to Flayn again. It was clear as day he was only delaying the inevitable. With a tired sigh he relented. He knew one day she would have to go into battle and stand on her own. He just never thought it would be today. "Do you think you can best them?"

"I will." She said. "I have no choice."

"She will win." Byleth added. "Because today she doesn't fight alone"

"What do you mean?"

"I mean I'm going with her, Seteth. And so are you."

The man's eyes widened. "Are we to become giants as well?

"Not possible." answered Lysithea. "But you will be her support. So stand back and get ready."

Both did as they were told.

"I hope you're ready Flayn. There may be some momentary discomfort."

Flayn nodded and embraced the magic.
_____

Edelgard surveyed the remainder of the battlefield while Petra cheered for their supposed victory over the Blue Lions and Golden Deer. She couldn't deny that victory tasted sweet, even if the battle didn't go as expected. Honestly, this was a mock battle that the officer academy would never forget.

She was about to call out to her fellow classmate until she felt a bizarre feeling on her abdomen. It happened repeatedly like someone was poking her. Turning to the side to see who the culprit was, she was shocked to see another giant had entered the fray. It wasn't just any giant either. She was slightly shorter but Edelgard knew that long and green hair anywhere. It was Flayn. She wasn't alone either as on each shoulder was none other than her annoyed brother, Seteth and an amused Byleth. Had Edelgard not been so stunned she would've found the sight amusing herself. It was like Flayn had a little angel and devil on her shoulder.

"Edelgard." Flayn addressed sternly, startling the Black Eagle leader. "It's time for you and Petra to lay down your arms and surrender."
142111223.title: Last Hope

choices: Flayn, Byleth, and Seteth are victorious
Edelgard and Petra are victorious and begin to rampage

1421112232.content:
Edelgard couldn't help but be surprised by Flayns forwardness. She didn't know the girl well, but from the few interactions she'd had with her the greenette struck her as the soft and gentle type. So hearing her speak with such authority in her voice gave her pause.

Still, this was the battle of Eagle and Lion and Flayn was a member of the Golden Deer house. That made her an enemy in the eyes of the Black Eagle house. Was she trying to make her and Petra surrender, to snatch victory away from them. Unacceptable! They'd gone through hell to attain victory and there was no way she'd allow the Golden Deer to take it from them.

"My apologies, Flayn. But we'll not surrender out victory to the Golden Deer after what we've been through." Edelgard stated. Her statement didn't go unnoticed as a both surprised and confused Petra made her way over to the two.

"What is the going on-- er, what is going on?" Petra asked/corrected.

"It would seem the Golden Deer are out to take our victory. A ploy by Claude and the Professor no doubt." The imperial Princess explained with narrowed eyes. Petra seemed to soak in her leader's words and soon mirrored her expression.

Flayn was surprised by the two's conclusion and hastily tried to explain the situation. "This is no ploy. The battle of Eagle and Lion is over. The Blue Lion's were defeated the moment Ingrid went down and before that the Golden Deer had already been disqualified by my brother!"

The two didn't look convinced.

"It's true!" Byleth added, finally joining the conversation. "Seteth disqualified us as soon as we unleashed Hilda on the battlefield."

"Lady Rhea was most upset by the turn of events. The battle of Eagle and Lion is a tradition of the Officer's Academy and all of you brought shame upon it by making a circus out of it!" said the normal sized greenette.

It was again Flayn's turn to speak. "This is why the other Golden Deer sent me here to confront you both. If you don't calm down and let Lysithea undo this spell, then Lady Rhea will take immediate action."

Hearing that the archbishop would get involved if they didn't end this gave the two giants pause. Flayn was giving them this information as well as the Professor and Seteth. Their fellow giantess must be telling the truth, but at the same time. This was still the Golden Deer house being led by a master schemer. How could they be sure Claude didn't put them up to this? Flayn and Byleth were the enemy and there was no question Seteth would side with them if Flayn was there.

In the end. The two giants couldn't trust their words.

"Sorry. But we are not believing you." Petra scowled, her pupils glowing a bright crimson. "You are wanting to take our victory away!"

The group looked shocked.

"She's right." Edelgard agreed as her eyes also began to glow very much the same. "You merely want to take the prestige of this great victory back to the Golden Deer house!"

Flayn began to back away slowly as her resolve wavered. Something clearly wasn't right here. "Brother? Professor?"

"Stay calm Flayn. We've got your back." Byleth assured. "Seteth. Get ready."

Seteth nodded. "Understood."

Everyone minus Petra drew their weapons. It would seem a battle was inevitable.
1421112232.title: One More Big Battle

choices: Hilda Vs the Knights of Seiros
142112.content:
Seteth was furious at the sudden turn of events at the Battle of Eagle and Lion. This was supposed to be a traditional battle of honor and respect and instead the Golden Deer house had to go and make a circus out of it. To think Professor Byleth would actually approve the use of a student as tactical weapon.

What was worse was said student had let the power go to her head and was now using the other two house leaders as dolls. Shockingly enough it would seem that the professor knew something like this would happen and did nothing. He merely chalked it up as learning experience for Claude. Seteth never felt more justified in his disqualification of the Golden Deer house. Now all that was left to do was summon the knights to clean up this mess before Lady Rhea's patience reached it's end.

Seteth landed his wyvern on a nearby hill not to far from the battle before reaching into his robe. There he pulled out what seemed to be a mini war horn. He took a deep breath and blew into it. It wasn't the loudest sound, especially with all the chaos going on on the battlefield, but it would do the job.

Sure enough the knights that were on standby raced to his position. There before him stood Jeralt, the father of professor Byleth, Lady Rhea's most faithful follower, Catherine, Alois, Gilbert, and the mercenary turned knight herself, Shamir. All present were on standby for the battle in case things went awry but honestly who could have prepared them for something like this? It wasn't as if they felled giants for a living.

Taking a second to calm his nerves, Seteth addressed his team. "I trust you know why I have summoned you all here?"

"Hilda's out of control." Jeralt answered.

The green haired man nodded. "That is correct. Our mission is to take her down by order of Lady Rhea."

"She doesn't want us to kill the girl does she?" Gilbert asked.

"Of course not. She's a student here same as the rest. This behavior must be a side effect of the spell." Alois cut in.

"Perhaps, perhaps not. It doesn't change out orders from Lady Rhea. If she wants us to fell a giant then we'll a giant." Cathrine said confidently. Though there was still worry in her eyes as she watched the giant pinkette play house with the Black Eagle fort.

"Easier said than done." Shamir scoffed. "Have any of us ever faced down a titan before?"

The silence was telling.

Shamir sighed. "Alright. Who's leading this operation?"

"Jeralt has the most combat experience here so it only makes sense he take charge." Seteth explained.

The elder knight nodded. "Very well. I might have an idea in mind but it's quite risky."

"No risk is to great. Just tell us what we have to do." said Catherine
_ _ _

Back on the battlefield Hilda was now using the Black Eagle's fort as a children's playhouse. Each and every member tried their best to avoid her massive hands reaching in to scoop them out. Bernadetta being the most successful at being elusive. "Oh come on guys stop struggling. Don't you wanna play with me?"

"If we make it out of this alive, I'm going to kill Claude and the professor." Hubert fumed.

"Get in line because I have a bone to pick with them too." Dorothea argued.

"Not if my hands are getting on them first." Petra added.

"I just want to go to my room!" Bernadetta panicked.

Suddenly the giant hand retracted, confusing the members of the Black Eagle house. The sounds of multiple footfalls and curses filled the air as they dared look outside. Much to their surprise they saw Seteth buzzing around her enormous face like a gnat. Had the situation not been so terrifying they'd find the scene quite funny.

"Damn it. What are you doing?!" Hilda complained as she used her free hand to try and swat the annoying wyvern rider. Her other hand contained both Dimitri and Edelgard who were both silently praying for a rescue soon.

Meanwhile on the ground the rest of the knights prepared to put the rest of captain Jeralt's plan into action. "Are you all ready?" The captain asked. The ground force nodded. "Alright then! Let's move out!"

The ground force of knights ran out from behind Hilda with an extremely large rope. "Remember then plan. While she's distracted wrap the rope around her ankles!"

"Roger that!"

And so the knights began their plan to fell the giantess known as Hilda. While Seteth distracted her like the most annoying bug he could possibly be, she never even realized the situation down by her feet. Within a matter of minutes the knights had her ankles wrapped and the giant's lower movements had ceased. By the time Hilda understood what was going on it was far too late.

Down she went. Taking her two captives with her. The knight all rushed away as fast as they could as Hilda's body collided with the earth. The shockwave was massive, sending dirt and debris in every direction. The knights themselves could do nothing as the dust cloud created by their little stunt swept them away.
_ _ _

"No way! The Knights of Seiros just toppled Hilda!" Claude exclaimed.

"Incredible!" Ignatz gawked.

"I.. I don't believe it." Lysithea said in awe.

"Ha! Leave it to the captain to pull off an incredible maneuver like that!" Leonie cheered.

"I hope Dimitri and Edelgard weren't hurt in the fall." Flayn worried.

That silenced the Golden Deer house.

"That's not good." Byleth said aloud.

"What's not good professor?" Claude asked.

"Take a good look at that dust cloud."

The Golden Deer did as instructed and saw that something was rising from within the dust cloud. It was BIG! SCARY! AND PINK! It was Hilda looking no worse for wear.

"Yeah. That's definitely not good." Claude.

Ignatz looked between the three remaining members of the Golden Deer who put this plan into motion. "What kind of spell did you three whip up?!"

Claude laughed nervously. "A really bad one."
142112.title: The Giant Slayers

143.content: Raphael Kirsten is the orphaned son of a pair of humble merchants. For a long time he tried to maintain his families business while living with his grandmother, all for the sake of his sister. Well aware that his muscular physique made him unsuited for merchant life, he worked to enter the officers academy and become a knight. Though he has the natural talent for the physical aspects, he has little skill for its tactical facets. A smaller size would force him to rely on his wits rather than his strength to survive.
143.title: Raphael: The Muscles

choices: Marianne, who was visiting her favorite horse, Dorte.
Catherine, looking for the knight Raphael helped.
1431.content:
(Set before the Chapter 7 mission in October. No spoilers.)

“Wraaaagh!” Raphael bellowed as he tossed a pile of horse saddles into an unruly heap next to the other supplies. Relieved of his load he took a deep breath and stretched, reaching his arms above his head. A small amount of perspiration dripped from his head, the only sign of strain from wielding such a heavy load.

Beside him, a lone knight clumsily let another saddle drop to the ground. She panted heavily, exhausted from lugging around equipment for the past hours. Raphael approached the woman with a warm smile. “You know, you’d probably be less tired if you didn’t wear all that heavy armor. It’s just weighing you down.” He gave her a hearty pat on the back, encouraging the knight to stand up straight.

“Even without this armor on, I would still be exhausted.” She groaned, short of breath.

“Well, guess you have been working for a couple hours. That was a lot of stuff to move for one knight.” Raphael mused, scratching his neck.

“And it would have been a few more if you hadn’t helped Raphael. Your muscles truly are good for tasks such as these.” The knight praised, before looking at Raphael’s work. Raphael had been a big help, bringing a lot of the supplies to the stables, but his organization skills left… much to be desired. The knight sighed wearily, she still had a lot of organizing to do before she could report her duties as finished.

Raphael, oblivious to the knights worries, laughed heartily. “Yeah, my muscles can be pretty handy.” He boasted, while flexing his bicep, straining his already tight clothes. ”When I saw how much stuff you had to haul I just knew I had to lend a hand.”

Figuring it was time for a break, the knight nodded and gave Raphael an appreciative pat on the back. “Thank you again for your help, I hope I didn’t take too much time away from your work.”

“Eh, don’t worry about it. I’m happy to help anytime!” Raphael waved as the knight left. He was always happy to help however he could. He had just gotten back from the marketplace outside of the monastery. As usual, he had picked up a lot of extra stuff around town. And even though he was hungry, he made certain not to eat any of the food he was sent for; didn’t want Claude to scold him again for the same mistake.

Rolling his shoulders, he returned to where he had left the supplies he’d picked up from town. There was all manners of food there, along with some books, weapons, and some training weights a merchant had been selling. “Kind of that knight to bring the stuff here for me. I would’ve hated having to go all the way back to the gate.”

Diligently, Raphael gather all of the items into a stack that he could carry. For most people the amount of stuff he had would be too great for one trip, but he knew he could handle it. As her gathered the last of the things, he looked up at a high shelf and realized something. “Oh, almost forgot those!” Setting down what he had, he moved over to the shelf.

On its surface was a box filled with an assortment of bottles filled with various liquids. This was the most interesting item that Raphael had picked up on his trip. He got them from a strange looking but friendly merchant that most people were ignoring. He had a lot of interesting looking stuff, including things like boar tusks, which Raphael also purchased off him. It was at the merchant’s recommendation that Raphael got the bottles. He talked about how they had all sorts of cool magical properties in them. He figured that Lysithea or some other mage in the monastery might want to take a look.

“I’m surprised the knight was able to get these up here.” Raphael said as he got on his tiptoes to grab the box. The shelf was really high off the ground, even he had problems reaching what he wanted! Grunting, he stretched as far as he could to wrap his hands around the small box. As one would expect Raphael lost his balance and ended up falling forward into the shelf! With a mighty crash, the shelf gave away under his massive frame and he tumbled to the ground. Unfortunately, the bottles were also a casualty of the accident; there contents spilling all over the massive blonde.

Sprawled out on the floor and soaking wet, Raphael groaned uncomfortably. “Aw, I ruined those bottles. I bet someone would’ve really liked ‘em.” He pushed a hand through his hair feeling how wet it was. He quietly wondered to himself if any of those bottles might have had poison in them. He knew Claude made that kind of stuff, so someone else could have too.

“Welp, no use worrying about it. I bet professor Manuela could cure anything like that.” He said getting to his feet. “I should get back to…” Raphael’s train of thought was interrupted when he saw his surroundings. Everything was gigantic now! The pile of supplies he had created was like a gigantic mountain in the distance, larger than even the monastery! Scattered all around him was the remains of the bottles he had broken, puddles of their content on the floor.

“Wow, I can’t believe it!” Raphael shouted, astounded. “Those potions were crazy powerful, I can’t believe I broke them like that!” He lamented. Only after he got over the wastefulness of his accident did he realize he had bigger issues to deal with, literally.

“Well this isn’t good. I can’t get anything done at this size. I gotta find help! But uh, I can’t exactly leave. The stables are far away from pretty much everywhere. Maybe I can wait for a knight to get back and get their attention…” Raphael brought his hand to his chin, considering his options. Staying would be the safest bet, but that could take a while. He could try to make it to a more crowded area, but that was pretty dangerous.

Raphael’s musing was interrupted by a knock on the door. From his spot on the floor, Raphael could see a shadow cast across the floor. “Huh, that’s lucky.” He thought optimistically. “I can get help from whoever’s coming in here!”

As if on cue, the doors swung open to reveal Raphael’s potential savior. It was...
1431.title: Losing More than Muscle Mass

choices: She doesn't see him, he follows her out the building.
14311.content:
The one who entered the room was none other than Marianne, one of Raphael’s fellow students from the Golden Deer house. Raphael was relieved to see someone he knew, especially someone as gentle as Marianne. He always thought she was too quiet and didn’t open up to people, though she had a fondness for animals. She could even communicate with them! Raphael had yet to figure out how to do that too.

“Um… hello?” The giant girl quietly called. The usually quiet girl’s voice was amplified for the tiny Raphael, though it was still quieter than what he thought a giant would sound like.

“I guess Marianne isn’t a ‘fee fi fo fum’ kind of gal.” Raphael quipped, keeping a positive attitude in spite of his dangerous situation.

Marianne, meanwhile, was very confused. She had just been visiting Dorte when she heard a crashing noise in one of the other buildings. She had expected to find someone inside but there was no one here. Nervously, she held her hands against her chest and moved past the door into the room. Surely there had to be someone here.

“Alright Raphael, just gotta get Marianne’s attention and you’ll be set. ...But how should I do that?” Raphael looked at the materials around him. He couldn’t really use anything to get Marianne’s attention. Nothing but broken glass or liquid near him. “Maybe if I just stay here and shout she’ll be able to hear.” Raphael’s decided on the simplest conclusion.

In the meantime, Marianne had gotten a good look at the stack of supplies that Raphael had made. “This looks like the stuff students have to pick up from the market in town. I wonder why it’s in the stable?” She wasn’t chosen for this task very often, but she guessed that it didn’t require stopping at the stables. “This is a big stack too…” She trailed off as she wiped a hand on top of a box. She rubbed her fingers together, checking for signs of dust or neglect.

“Aw man. I hope she doesn’t think I’m slackin’.” Raphael thought. “Hey Marianne! Look over here!” He shouted as loudly as he could. He knew he was pretty loud, plenty of folks told him that all the time.

Unfortunately for Raphael, even his shouting couldn’t reach Marianne when she was that far away. She was too occupied with her investigation to hear. Anxiously, she circled the pile to look for the source of the crash she heard. As she circled around, she noticed the broken shelf and shattered bottles of liquid. “Oh, is this it?”

Raphael’s heart began racing when Marianne looked in his direction. He was used to looking down at people when he was normal. So seeing Marianne loom over him in the distance was incredibly nerve wracking. The anxious feeling was only made worse once she started approaching him. The sight of the gentle Marianne become larger and larger, accompanied by the bombing of her footsteps, made Raphael break into a cold sweat.

Marianne looked over the mess Raphael carefully, checking her boot when she realized she stepped in some kind of liquid. She guessed that this was what had caused that noise, maybe it had fallen from the top of the pile? That idea was quickly removed from her mind when she noticed the partially collapsed shelf, currently hanging by one of its hinges. “That’s strange… I’m sure that wouldn’t just collapse. Perhaps whoever broke it ran off?”

Marianne turned to look towards the door once again. She hadn’t seen anyone leave in a hurry, but someone breaking the shelf made the most sense. Worried that she was going to leave him behind, Raphael began shouting again and waved up at the giant girl. “Marianne! Look down here! By the mess!” Whether it was Raphael’s shouting or something else, Marianne turned herself back to the mess. Carefully, she got onto her knees and looked at the mess, picking up a shard of glass and looking it over.

“These were obviously some kind of concoction, but what did they do? I hope they’re nothing like what Claude makes.” She mumbled the last part, nervous about anyone hearing her say something unpleasant.

“No, I’d dare say they’re worse.” Raphael grumbled, wiping at his head. Eager to be seen, he continued to shout and gesture to Marianne as she examined his mess. Surely she would be able to see him when she was this close. He might of shrunk, but he knew he wasn’t that hard to see… probably.

Marianne looked over the mess with casual interest, she had no idea that the well being of one of her classmates was dependent on her careful eyes...

1441.content:
Spoilers for Chapter 8 and Marianne's paralogue. Mild content warning for violence.

*


Claude was no stranger to violence. Their months at the Monastery thus far had given them valuable battlefield experience, and coupled with their cool composure, the future leader to the Alliance was convinced that there was little out there that could faze them.

Remire Village had proven him wrong.

The smell of smoking wood and charred flesh was impossible to ignore as Claude dashed through the village alongside their stalwart professor. He’d never show the discomfort and disgust, of course - a leader’s gotta keep it together no matter what, right? - but he could tell that this scene would be playing back in his sleep for a long while.

Byleth, ever the stoic, showed no sign of slowing down as they led the charge, barely regarding the burning buildings or the corpses that decorated their hellish landscape. As two assailants emerged from behind cover to try and pick off Byleth and Claude with throwing daggers, Byleth whisked their relic sword like a whip and cut the men down without a hint of emotion on their face.

Damn, Teach. I guess that’s why they call you the Ashen Demon, huh...?

“Do you see anyone?” Byleth announced, shaking the sword once with their strong arm to shed some of the blood before retracting its whip-like form back to normal.

“Can’t say I have yet,” Claude said, keeping pace while picking off a third assassin hiding behind a nearby barrel with a well-aimed shot from his bow. “Unless you count the bad guys, of course.”

It was difficult to keep the levity in such a grim situation. Aside from the horror of the village going up in smoke as half of its citizens seemed consumed by some strange bloodlust, the Golden Deer had gotten separated amidst the chaos. Byleth jarred themselves to the side as they spotted another group of villagers under attack. “Don’t worry, Claude. They’ll be okay.”

“Of course, Teach. This is a cakewalk after what you’ve trained us through, right?”

Claude readied his bow, the string dug deep into his fingers. Everyone in their house could hold their own in a fight.

Except for maybe one...

*


Marianne stumbled through the blood-soaked mud, her uniform caked and torn amidst the attackers that she had evaded thus far. She had managed to slip away from the maddened villagers with their sickles and pitchforks, but she could feel the exhaustion setting in. Her talent in healing injuries didn’t extent to herself. Self-care had never been her strong suit.

The mage had gotten separated early on when one of the houses nearby fell to pieces, the stonework barring her intended path to keep formation with Raphael. Her cries for aid had been drowned out amidst the licking of flames and the clashing of iron. Now, she was alone on the battlefield, with no idea where Claude or Byleth or anyone else might be.

A blast of dark magic erupted from around the corner of a nearby stable. Marianne shrieked and threw herself to the side behind an overturned cart. She couldn’t even tell if that had been aimed for her. It was such a chaotic situation that she could barely tell where she was or where to go. Where was the professor when she needed him...?

Marianne heard the whinnying of horses from afar, only for it to be cut short by the telltale sound of lances skewering through meat. She felt her blood run cold, the fear threatening to overtake her entirely.

And now, somewhere deep in her bones, something was snapping.

“N-No!” Marianne cried out, her worst fear now coming to life. There was all manner of dark legend about what the Crest of the Beast could do, and she had spent so long keeping it buried as deep as possible, but the smell of hot blood and the sight of frayed meat around her was enticing it like bait. “I-I won’t...!”

A rumble of thunder echoed across the distance. A scream died out with a gurgle. No matter where she turned, Marianne saw death.

Did her throat always feel so dry? Was the sound of her heartbeat always so deafening? Was there blood seeping in her gums or was it simply her imagination? The girl doubled over, wincing as pain bellowed from inside her every pore. She dug her hands into her ribs, trying to contain whatever was threatening to burst out from her frail cage of skin and bone.

No matter her conviction, it was no match for the Crest of the Beast. Marianne fell to her knees, her breath thin and ragged as if she were being choked by an invisible force. A guttural noise - somewhere between the wheezing of a broken throat and the snarl of a feral animal - escaped her lips.

Marianne disappeared as her eyes went as blank and white as snow.

*


Claude clambered atop a tree that had miraculously remained untouched by the fires thus far (although he didn’t intend to stay up for any longer than he needed to.) He squinted as he scanned the roads around him, trying to spot anyone in a familiar yellow uniform to assist.

A few houses away, there was a flash of steel as Lorenz fought back against a robe-clad madman, the lance deflecting their attack with ease.

“Not my first choice, but now’s not the time to be picky...” Claude muttered to himself, before turning his head down to inform the awaiting professor of his discovery. “Hey, Teach, I spotted Lorenz. He’s over by-”

The whole village seemed to shake as something erupted in the distance. Byleth staggered and leaned against the tree for support while Claude had to swiftly wrap his hands around the nearest branch for fear of falling straight down.

What was that? An explosion? What could cause an explosion like that-?!

A bestial roar followed, deep and feral. Claude turned his head back, staring out towards the edge of the village. The blanket of gray clouds in the sky and the vista of trees lining around the village border shielded the area from light, but the fires below were just enough illumination to show the source of the bloodcurdling noise.

A looming figure, towering high above the fragile buildings below, bellowed with rage. The creature looked vaguely humanoid, yet from what details he could make out from the distance, it definitely reminded Claude of the Black Beast that Miklan had transformed into. It also reminded him of something else, yet he couldn’t quite place it...

The savage giant advanced. The Beast was free.
1441.title: The Beast Was Free

Marianne manages to take control over the beastly impulses.

14412.content:
(Alternative Spoilery Title: Her Ancestors Were Cursed, Therefore She’s Cursed. Also, heavy violence warning.)

Claude studied the monster in the distance. Its form was obscured mostly by the heavy smoke rising into the air. He couldn’t help but approach, his unquenchable thirst for knowledge beating out the natural instincts to stay away and stay alive. However, as he passed crow of wrecked buildings blocking his view, he caught onto a metal he could hardly believe.

The monster was wearing a torn Officer’s Academy uniform.

“What the…?” He rushed forward, shooting warning shots at deranged villagers that charged at him. Once struck a guy in the thigh and sent him collapsing onto a pile of rubble. He rounded corners and even cut through some trees until he was at the base of the monsters feet and got a good look at the beast.

What told him all he needed to know about the identity of the monster was the sheer amount of light blue hair everywhere. There was only one person in the academy with hair like that, but he was having rouble comprehending just what caused this to happen.

“M-Marianne!?” He gasped, keeping his bow at the ready. “Oh, Goddess, what did Tomas do to you? I should’ve kept an eye on…”

He found himself staring at the beast-like features. Her nails had grown long and turned black, resembling claws more than they did fingernails. Her teeth had also elongated, her canines much more pronounced. Her eyes now had anger in them rather than the tired, defeated look. Her ears were pointed and her hair, normally kept up and out of the way, rolled down her back, much longer than it should have been.

This is the same sweet Marianne you know, Claude reminded himself. Just as he finished, Marianne swept up an encroaching Flame Emperor Soldier and brought him to her mouth, mercilessly sinking her teeth into his chest and tearing him in half as she shook her neck like a feral animal. The cracking of bones snapping and flesh tearing ingrained itself into the house leader's ears.

Claude wretched at the sight as Marianne casually tossed the remaining half of the body aside. It hit the roof of a building with a vivid splat. He was just glad wasn’t an innocent. However, he knew that his perception of Marianne would change after this.

Then the giantess’ eyes stared back at him. Claude began to back away, pulling at the drawstring of his bow. She stepped closer, her footfalls shaking the ground at her feet.

“Easy, Marianne,” Claude said, still backing away. “I’m a friend. I don’t want to hurt you. I just want to help.”

It didn’t take long before he backed into what was the last undamaged building in Remire. He slowly took aim, waiting ro the precise moment she was close enough. He didn’t want to hit anything vital, but he needed to stun her just long enough to make an escape.

He let an arrow loose sending it into the giantess’ cheek. She let out a pained roar, sending a combination of spit and blood flying everywhere. She lifted her foot high into the air and over the archer. Claude managed to duck out of the way and into the cover of the trees moments before the massive boot crashed into the building, reducing it to rubble.

She turned her attention towards him again, beginning another march. Another pained roar escaped her lips as collapsed to the ground, nearly pinning him under her body. Half of the patch of forest he was in was taken down beneath her weight.

The telltale sound of a chain went through the air as the Sword of the Creator whipped back into place. The expression on the mercenary turned professor’s face remained stoic, despite having to do battle with one of their students.

Does anything rattle Teach? Claude thought, getting up and rushing to the professor’s side.
