She shrunk while she was asleep!
14521.content:
(Post Chapter 7, pre-Chapter 8, No spoilers)

*Creak*

Lysithea felt another wave of goosebumps on her arms at the sound of a creak in the night. It was a late night, a few days after the battle of the Eagle and the Lion. Even Lysithea had a small smile on her lips thinking about how proud Claude was after the Golden Deer had won the battle. “I wonder if they’ll keep calling this ‘The Battle of the Eagle and Lion’. We trounced the other Houses so badly I believe a new name is in order. Let’s call it ‘The Effortless Victory of the Deer’.” That Claude was quite a character, but Lysithea could not argue against his well earned pride after the battle. She herself had done quite-

*Creeeeeak*

Lysithea cringed involuntarily, startled by yet another creak in the night. She growled in frustration, she simply had to get over her fears. She had just been part of a big mock battle with plenty of talented students, one that people were still resting from, and she hardly flinched at all. But one creak in a dark library in the middle of night put her on edge; ridiculous! All because of a fear of ghosts she knew she should’ve outgrown by now.

“Honestly, I should be better than this.” She grumbled to herself, continuing to look through the books on the library shelf. The library was rather creepy in its current state. It was rather late at night, so late that even Annette of the Blue Lions, who’d work so long in the library she’d fall asleep, was gone! It certainly didn’t help that Tomas, the man who would usually be managing the library, even at this time of night, had disappeared for quite a while now. So Lysithea was completely alone in a dark library in the middle of the night, well past the bedtime some of the Golden Deer joked with her about.

“I simply have to put this ridiculous fear of mine to rest, it’s holding me back more than it should.” She said, greatly exaggerating how much effect it had on her. She couldn’t help but be hard on herself at the moment, the creepy atmosphere would feed the fears of anyone with her kind of phobia. This was the only time of day where she could safely accomplish what she wanted to. Well, safely was exaggerating, least embarrassing time was more accurate. Some of her housemates already knew about her fear, but letting them see her looking for a solution meant she would acknowledge it in front of them. For now, Lysithea would rather ineffectually deny she had any such fear.

After a while of searching, and a few more startling creaks, Lysithea finally found something that could help her. In one of the more hidden corners of the library, she found a book dedicated to spirits and methods to ward them off. To Lysithea’s dismay, this book was the only one of its kind, nothing else in the library even discussed the idea of ghosts. “I guess this will have to do.” Lysithea whispered as she began flipping through the book. She knew that what she was looking for was likely at the end.

Her intuitions were proven right as there was a spell at the end of the book that was perfectly suited for helping her put her fears to rest. “Finally! A spell that will help me ward off all those creepy ghosts.” Lysithea daintily folded the corner of the page she was on and held it against her chest. She’d usually have a bookmark, but she didn’t want to bother with it on this night. “Once I cast this, I’ll be able to forget all about ghosts and never be afraid of them again.” Lysithea let out a frightened squeal when another creak echoed in the library, as if the ghosts were calling her bluff. “T-time for bed!” The white haired girl croaked, setting her now extinguished candle on a nearby table. It was so dark now that she had simply decided to use a single cast of her Fire spell to light the world around her instead of a candle. It certainly wasn’t so she could defend herself from any ghosts wanting to steal the book from her.

Though the trip felt like an eternity, Lysithea was able to make it back to her room unharmed by any ghosts. The worst part was getting into her room; she had moved so quickly to open and close the door that she improperly canceled her Fire spell, burning her hand a bit. The young girl was so anxious that she didn’t even bother to get out of her uniform, instead diving under the covers of her bed, apparently a safe haven from ghosts. Eagerly, she opened up the book back to where she left off, making sure to undo the fold she had made.

Her eyes quickly scanned across the page, only confirming the details she considered the most important. The spell would indeed ward off any spirits and she didn’t have to worry about recasting it, ever. It was a one time spell that required a lot of magical energy to pull off. Of course Lysithea had plenty of that to spare, so she cast the spell as soon as she found the method. A feeling of comfort washed over the girl as she felt the spell take effect. With a sigh of relief, she shut the book and deposited it on a nearby shelf. Tired from the long night, she closed her eyes and drifted off to sleep feeling safe with her new spell working.

Lysithea had no idea that the spell she had used was going to a lot more than make her forget about her fear of ghosts. In the morning she would wake up, noting that her room had changed a lot since she fell asleep. What did her haphazard spell casting do to her?
14521.title: The Ghosts Left No Choice!

choices: The mages can't find the book at all.
145211.content:
Lysithea woke up to a nagging pain in her neck. She groaned and rubbed at the sore spot. The only time she felt this was when she slept on her pillow wrong. However, when she opened her eyes, she quickly picked up that something was wrong.

Her entire body was cramped inside the dorm.

“Wh-what the!?” She yelped, realizing that she was trapped in her own bedroom. Her head was up against her wall, and she was crunched up in a fetal position, taking up nearly every inch of the room. “S-someone help!”

She kicked at the walls to her side, not caring if she woke up her dorm neighbors. She lived on the first floor, and all she needed to do was to get out of the door, and she would be in the open air area between the dining hall and the greenhouse. The last thing she wanted was to have another growth spurt and tear down the dorm building. Or even worse.

Lysithea’s thoughts were shaken away as there was a pounding at her door.

“Lysithea! The sun’s not even out yet!” Leonie yelled, still unaware of her classmate’s sudden affliction.

“What’s going on?” asked a soft spoken voice. Mercedes had just got out of her own room, still dressed in a large sleep robe.

The answer came as the the white haired girl forced her door open, revealing her giant frame taking up almost the entirety of the entrance. “H-help!”

“Oh, dear Goddess,” Leonie gasped. “Wh-what do we do?”

“Get me out of here!”

Leonie nodded. “Right, I’ll go grab help.”

The redhead quickly turned the corner of the dorm and ran up the stairs. She had found the other students of he academy standing around, trying to figure out the source of the earthquake.

“Are we under attack?” Caspar asked excitedly. His expression soured. “The one night Professor Manuela took my sleeping axe.”

Leonie ignored the strange comment. “No, nothing like that, just head to the first floor. We’re gonna need all the manpower we can get.” She ran down the hall, waking up everyone she could and directing them to Lysithea’s room.

When she returned outside, she found a crowd forming as Lysithea was halfway out the door, caught by her hips. Caspar, Raphael, and Claude grappled onto one of her wrists while Dimitri, Dedue, and Edelgard grabbed the other. Everyone was still in there sleepwear, and had the situation not been terrifying, the sight would have been funny to witness.

Leonie decided to join in, heading right towards the door, where Mercedes was trying to help guide the massive body into exiting the gap.

“Gotta say, Lysithea,” Claude began, his tone clearly a set up for a joke. “You should lay off the cakes. It’s going straight to your hips.”

Lysithea groaned. “Make one more joke, and I’m eating you.”

“Alright fine,” Claude said with a laugh. “Just thought you’d be big enough to overlook my jokes.”

The giantess didn’t dignify it with a response.

Leonie noticed that the archway was beginning to crack under he pressure of Lysithea’s body. “Uh, guys.”

“Keep pulling!” Raphael instructed, motivating the others with his guttural yells. “HRAGH”

“I don’t think this wall’s gonna hold,” Leonie continued, drowned out by the others joining Raphael.

“On three. One, two. THREE!”

With a major tug, the wall crumbled, and Lysithea spilled out onto the the small courtyard. The sudden momentum had caused her to bowl over those who helped her free, pinning them under her. She let out a yelp as she felt her classmates squirm under her. She pushed herself up, forcing herself up to her full height and get a look at how tall she was.

She was currently a few feet shorter than the dorm building, yet she still was roughly triple the heights of the other students. Even Dedue, the tallest student at the academy, was still dwarfed by the white haired giantess.

“Um… thanks everyone,” Lysithea said sheepishly, feeling suddenly embarrassed once everyone’s eyes were on her .”S-sorry for waking you all up.”

“What happened?” Claude asked, stashing away his jokes for now.

“Um, magic mishap,” Lysithea admitted, staring down at her feet. The cobblestone was freezing, and she wished she kept her shoes on when she jumped into bed. At the very least, she was still in her uniform and not in her pajamas like the rest of the students. “I’m gonna need some help reading the spell book, so I can change back.”

Mercedes stepped forward. “Annie and I would be glad to help.”

“Th-thanks,” she looked back to her room, finding it practically destroyed. In fact, the first floor was practically gone as the wall took out Mercedes and Leonie’s room. “The spell book should be in my room… somewhere. Sorry for destroying your rooms.”

“No worries,” Mercedes said sweetly. “I’ll just bunk with Annie.”

Leonie bit her tongue. She wasn’t taking the loss of her dorm as lightly. Though, maybe she could room with Jeralt until they fixed her room.
145211.title: A Large Lysithea

choices: Byleth finds the book out in the open
Lady Rhea and the knights come to investigate
1452112.content:
Leonie was pacing back and forth as everyone discussed what would happen next. Lysithea did her best to maintain her composure despite her situation. It was admirable how she tried to stay calm and not freak out. If she did she would most likely accidently damaged the students dorms... more than she already had.

"We can't find it." Mercedes said as she and Annette emerged from the remains of the giantess dorm.

"What do you mean you can't find it?" Lysithea asked warily. Without that spellbook she might be stuck like this.

"We mean we can't find it." Annette reaffirmed. "We searched that rubble from to bottom. We even searched Mercy and Leonie's rooms. It's just not here."

Lysithea felt ill. No book meant no cure. Or to be more accurate it would be much more difficult to find solution. Everyone else present seemed to realize what that meant for their giant friend.

Before anyone else could suggest any form of solution, the telltale sounds of footsteps echoed through the empty dorms. Everyone turned to the source to find a yawning professor Byleth fully dressed in his battle attire. He must not have noticed the situation yet because he seemed to preoccupied rubbing the sleep from his eyes.

"What are you all doing out here? Don't you know what... time... it... is." the professor trailed off as he finally became aware of the now towering Lysithea and the wide eyed students. Everyone had gone silent as he looked between the giantess, students, and destroyed dorms. All while his face remained as blank as humanly possible.

"Uh... high professor." Lysithea waved awkwardly.

"Good morning. Would anyone care to explain how all of... this came to be?"

After short but sweet explanation, all Byleth could do was no his head. While Lysithea left out some minor details, knowing her he had a pretty good idea what they were. Walking into the destroyed remains of her room and surveying the area, he could picture everything the students told him.

To think he'd be greeted with this when he first woke up.
1452112.title: Professor We Have A Problem

choices: The very stressed Lysithea grows again!
The other students discuss what to do with Lysithea.
1452113.content:
Now that all of the students had been made aware of Lysithea's predicament, several groups formed and responded in their own ways. Mercedes, Annette, and Leonie were looking through the ruins of the dorms. There was a lot of to look through, though they were thankful that the upper story hadn't collapsed as well. Leonie wondered if she should have comforted her classmate a bit more, but she was frustrated with the loss of her room and she knew some work would help her stay calm. Mercedes was simply helping out of the goodness of her heart, Annette simply helping her best friend.

Lysithea sat on the stairs leading up to the mess hall, her arms wrapped around herself. She was understandably on edge at her new size, she felt every fidget of her body. She did have issues with being one of the shortest students in the past, but now she missed being shorter than everyone. After she had unintentionally destroyed three room just by squeezing out of her own, she was concerned for what her new size would do to her classmates if she was careless. Every time someone from another house looked in her direction, she felt sick. She hadn't been particularly warm to most of them, just what were they thinking about her?

The other members of the Golden Deer were trying their best to comfort their massive friend. Raphael was certainly the most talkative of her supporters. "Don't worry about it Lysithea. If you think about it, this is pretty cool! Imagine how much muscle power your new size gives you!"

"I doubt that she cares about such things Raphael." Lorenz rolled his eyes at his large friend. His mind was still on muscles, even in this fantastic situation. "Lysithea, do you feel ill?" He addressed the girl directly, hoping to distract her.

Lysithea turned her focus away from the other students and looked at Lorenz. He tended to infuriate her, but he seemed sincerely concerned right now. "No I'm alright, just a little nervous."

Lorenz nodded in understanding. "That is understandable. You are handling yourself very well, I am certain that Leonie will find your book soon. If necessary I will lend my own magical talent to aid you."

"As will I." Marianne added. She was rubbing Lysithea's left shoulder, working with Ignatz to ease the tension in her shoulder. "I'm not much help but every bit of magic should be useful."

"You can count on me too." Ignatz spoke from the other shoulder. "It's been some time, but I can work a little magic myself."

"And I will provide moral support!" Hilda perked up. The others glared at her, her usual laziness wouldn't cut it today. "You guys! Of course I'm going to do more than that. Someone will need to help her get ready in the morning."

"Yeah. I'm no good at magic stuff... or book stuff in general, but I can still help out. I'll bring you anything you need. I'd even bring you a whole cow if you were hungry!"

Hearing Raphael say that put a gruesome image in Lysithea’s mind. The idea of eating a whole cow made her sick, but more troubling it made her seem like a monster. She imagined the look of horror on people’s face if anyone saw her eat a whole animal. The thought made her flinch. She covered her face with her hands, her shoulders tensed so hard that Ignatz and Marianne were nearly tossed to the ground, and a squeak of terror escaped her.

“Uh… was it something I said?” Raphael got a swift slap in the back of the head from Lorenz.

Down on the fishing pier, Claude was gathered with the leaders of the other houses. The other two had called him over to get information. They were frustrated to learn that he had no idea how this happened. “Trust me, I have no idea how this happened.” He insisted honestly. “If I did, I likely would have used it to make our last battle a literal stomping rather than a figurative one.”

Ignoring Claude’s taunting, Dimitri spoke, “That is unfortunate. I suppose we will have to wait until we find the book. Hopefully the spell can be reversed.”

Edelgard nodded, “Indeed. She seems understandably distraught, the quicker we find a solution the better.”

“Well aren’t you two astute, stating the obvious.” Claude shook his head. “I don’t think things will be as simple as: find the book, cast the spell backwards, and everything’s normal. It could take quite a while before we fix out dear Lysithea.

Edelgard’s expression soured. “Of course I know that, I just thought we should focus on the best case scenario. As the leaders of our houses, we must ensure that we set a good example for our fellows.”

“You are, of course, right Edelgard.” Dimitri tried to assuage the future empress, “But Claude also has a point. We must not only focus on the best outcome. We should, at least, consider how we will explain these… changes to the professors and the knights.”

Keeping their distance away from the giant girl, but trying not to look like they were doing so, were the members of the other houses. “I can’t believe how big Lysithea is now!” Caspar shouted excitedly, earning him harsh shushes from everyone around him.

“You moron! Don’t go shouting things like that around her. She’s clearly upset.” Dorothea scolded.

“Indeed.” Ferdinand began, ready to go on one of his spiels. “One should never be so careless about their words around someone in distress.”

Linhardt yawned loudly. For once, his tiredness was actually justified. “I wonder what kind of spell it was that could lead to such a spectacular result. This clearly isn’t what she wanted, but its impressive all the same.” Another yawn escaped him as he lazily stretched. “I’m going back to sleep, I will see you all in the morning.”

“Wait, you can’t just leave! What if they need our help?” Ingrid protested as the layabout left.

“U-um. I-I’m going to head back to my room too.” Bernadetta squeaked, already trying to slink away.

“Bernadetta…” Dorothea began before stopping. She knew that there was no way that Bernie was going to stay, she was shocked she had even come out at all, in her pajamas even! “Just try to be stealthy, it’ll probably hurt Lysithea if she saw you running away from her.” The purple haired girl simply nodded and hurried off back to her room.

“I’m not going to waste my time. This has nothing to do with me, I’ll see you all in the morning. Try to get some sleep.” Felix left, unconcerned with whatever happened.

“Come on Felix.” Sylvain groaned. “Couldn’t you have shown just a little support?”

In the rubble of the dorms, Leonie overturned another piece of wood to find nothing under it. “Goddess, this is such a mess. Is the book even still here?”

“Found it!” Leonie heard two voices say at the same time.

“Oh, good. I getting worried for a second there.”

“Um, Annie? Did you say you found the book?” Mercedes called to her friend.

“Yeah… but didn’t you just say that too?”

An awkward silence hung between the three searchers before a realization dawned on them.

“Oh no…” The three said in unison.

- - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - -

Doing their best to remain discreet, the trio had made there way to the pier and discussed their findings. Unknown to them, a curious Caspar had followed behind, having been pushed out of the conversation with the other students.

Ashamed, Mercedes and Annette presented their findings to the three house leaders. Both held a torn half of Lysithea’s book, the pages shredded or torn out. Leonie had a small collection of paper in her arms, but they amounted to little more than various scraps. “We’re really sorry!” Annette apologized, clearly distressed. “We just found the book like this, Leonie helped us get some of the missing pages but…”

“But they’re just scraps…” Claude mourned, holding his head in a hand. “Crap.”

Caspar had now put himself in position to listen in on the conversation, wondering what he had missed while trying to hide.

“This is quite troublesome.” Edelgard’s brow furrowed. She had feared the book would be damaged, but she hadn’t thought it would be this bad.

“Yes, it is. We must keep this a secret. It would be easier for people to think the book was just lost. We cannot let anyone, especially Lysithea, know that it was destroyed.” Dimitri said seriously.

Unfortunately for everyone, Caspar heard that part of the conversation loud and clear. “The book was destroyed!?” He unintentionally shouted, loud enough for all nearby to hear.

“W-what!?” Lysithea’s reaction could also be heard by everyone nearby.

“Uh-oh.” Caspar turned to the leaders of the houses. “Uh… I messed up.” Leonie had a few choice words for the short loudmouth.

Meanwhile, Lysithea’s stress peaked higher than it ever was before. Holding her head in her hands, she nervously mumbled to herself. “Without the book, it’ll be much harder to figure out a cure! How long am I going to be like this? What if the knights think I’m a monster and chase me out? What if-” The girl continued to mutter to herself, her housemates’ attempt to calm her doing little.

“Well, this is quite a conundrum.” Claude shrugged, trying to keep a cool disposition.
1452113.title: Broken Books are the Worst

choices: Lysithea will hide in the monastery, waiting for a solution.
14521132.content:
“Lysithea… Lysithea.” Ignatz repeatedly tried to get the giant girl’s attention to no avail. The white haired giantess was in a panicked stupor, imagining all kinds of horrible scenarios. What if society abandoned her, kicked her out? She’d have to get adopted by a pack of giant wolves and live with them! Then, when one of the wolves inevitably ended up in a fight with some thieves or soldiers, she’d have to help protect the only thing she could call family. She’d probably end up as a joint house assignment, the house to get the killing blow would get an extra reward and-

“Lysithea!” Another familiar voice called out to the distressed girl, but this one got her attention. Though it was familiar, the voice was louder and more assured than usual. She recognized it as Marianne’s voice. Still scared, but drawn to Marianne’s voice, Lysithea uncovered her face and turned to Marianne. Her usual tired look was gone, replaced by a determined and understanding look.

“Lysithea, it’s alright.” Marianne spoke softly, stroking Lysithea’s hair. “You’re not a monster, you’re a good friend to all of us.”

Lysithea stared at the blue haired girl amazed. “H-how did you guess that’s what I was thinking?”

Marianne smiled gently. “It’s kind of easy to tell. You just have to read between the lines.” She neglected to mention that she understood that feeling. “I know what you’re going through is scary, but hang in there. We all just want to help. We aren’t going to leave you.”

Lystihea, relieved to hear those words, let her body relax. “Thanks Marianne… I needed to hear that.” She could feel her nerves starting to go away a tiny bit. She could finally try to relax a little.

“Alright Marianne! Who’d have thought that you would be so good at comforting people?” Marianne could only blush and stutter a response.

“Indeed, you did quite well.” Lorenz added. “Now then. Lysithea, is there anything I can do to help you right now? Just ask and I will do my best to assist you.” Lysithea looked at Lorenz and then at the ground. She was embarrassed to say it, but he had asked…

“My feet are freezing.”

Lorenz gentle smile immediately disappeared. “Ah I see. Well I think I have a way to fix that, but-”

“You could use your fire magic to warm them right?” Hilda suggested helpfully.

Lorenz subdued a growl and glared at the pink haired bum, who winked at him coyly. “Indeed. That was what I was going to suggest.” He forced himself to say.

“I-it’s alright!” Lysithea squeaked. “It’s just cold feet, it’s not a big deal!”

Lorenz desperately wanted to agree with Lysithea, but his noble nature would not allow it. And he knew Hilda would say something if he didn’t. “Please, it is a noble’s duty to help a fair girl such as yourself with any problem she has. I shall… warm your feet for you.” Having said his piece, Lorenz moved down the stairs towards Lysithea’s feet. The white haired giantess squeaked an apology.

Lysithea’s feet bashfully rubbed against each other as Lorenz approached, occasionally twitching. Lysithea felt horribly embarrassed and regretted ever saying anything. Lorenz felt a similar sentiment when he was ready to begin. His irritation rose when he heard Hilda giggled in a wicked tone. “How noble of you Lorenz.” She started, amusement poorly disguised. “I’ll be sure to include this in my letter to my brother when I praise your other deeds.”

“I’d rather you not, really. I do not want to risk him thinking I have an interest in this sort of thing.” Lorenz answered without looking at Hilda. With a snap of his fingers, he produced a flame he assumed large enough to warm Lysithea’s feet. With great reluctance, he held it close to her massive feet, which seemed to relax in response. Lorenz heard Lysithea offer a meek thanks and he forced himself to smile and nod.
-----
“I can’t believe that you would just shout that outloud!” Leonie continued tear into Caspar, giving yet another slap on the head. She had been giving Caspar a piece of her mind for a couple minutes now, the excitable boy held up his arms to defend himself, fearing any serious assault from the upcoming mercenary. He was starting to think that she was taking her frustration about her destroyed room out on him.

Seeing that Edelgard wasn’t coming to his rescue, Claude decided to speak up. “Leonie, give Caspar a break. We don’t want him broken too.” He nodded appreciatively when Leonie stopped. “Good, now I need you to go help the others calm down Lysithea." Leonie simply nodded and left to go help Lysithea, Caspar cautiously followed behind, not wanting to look like he was running away.

“I’ll go too.” Annette said, handing her half of the book to Mercedes. “I want to apologize about what happened.” She quickly dismissed herself and followed after Leonie.

“I’ll just take everything we found and store it somewhere. Does anyone have a place in mind?” Mercedes asked, stacking the torn halves with as many scraps as she could in between.

“If you wouldn’t mind, drop them off in my room.” Claude suggested. “She’s part of my house, so I’ll take responsibility.” Mercedes nodded sweetly and started the walk to Claude’s room.

“This is troublesome.” Dimitri began. “With the book in the condition it is, I doubt it will be of any help.”

Claude shook his head solemnly. “Agreed. But I’ll keep it around just in case, perhaps we can use its remains later. Let’s forget about that for now. We need to figure out what to do with Lysithea.”

“It seems obvious enough to me.” Edelgard began. “We should report this to your professor as soon as possible.”

“I agree, that seems the most logical course of action.” Dimitri added.

Claude sighed and crossed his arms. “Do you two really think that’s for the best? You see how nervous she is, you thinking bringing more people to see her will help?”

“And what would you suggest, Claude, if our answer is unacceptable?”

Uncrossing one arm, Claude motioned outward to some direction. “I say we remove her from the monastery. We can take her to where we had our first mock battle. It’s close and there won’t be dozens of strangers staring at her every moment she’s there.” He stressed the last part of the sentence, trying to show why Edelgard’s idea was wrong. “We can bring the professors and a select group of others over later. And the Golden Deer could have class outside for a while.” He joked.
----
“Uh, Lorenz? What are you doing?” Leonie asked, baffled by what she was seeing.

“Lysithea informed me that her feet were cold. So, as a gentlemen and noble should, I insisted I help her warm up.” Lorenz spoke elegantly. “Plus, Hilda was going to say something if I didn’t after I offered to help.” He added bitterly.

“Okay… I guess that makes sense. Keep up the good work?” Leonie answered uncertainly before going past Lorenz and up the stairs. At the top Leonie found Lysithea and the others standing around her. “Hey Lysithea, how are you feeling?”

Lysithea eyes widened hearing Leonie, quickly returning to normal. “Oh, Leonie… sorry about your room.” She apologized.

Leonie frowned and waved her hand dismissively. “Forgot about that.” She insisted, mostly for herself. “I just want to make sure your fine.”

Lysithea tried to have a relaxed smile. “I’m doing alright. Or as well as I can. I freaked out a bit for a moment, but Marianne helped me get it under control.”

“Really? I remember you freaking out more than once.” Raphael said.

“Alright, I might have panicked a little more than once. But only one time was really bad.” Lysithea insisted.

“Well I’m glad that you’re doing alright. A few freak outs is alright.”

“H-hey Lysithea.” A nervous voice spoke out. Leonie scowled when she saw it was Caspar. The blue haired boy had gone up the other side of the stairs, making sure to be on the other side of Lysithea safe from Leonie. “Sorry I just shouted about the book being destroyed. That probably wasn’t the best way to give you the news.”

Lysithea looked at the Caspar confused. “It’s fine. It wasn’t really the best way to hear it but I would’ve heard about it sooner or later. It’s better than being lied to about it being lost. How bad is the book anyways?”

“It’s pretty bad.” Leonie admitted bluntly. “It’s torn in two and a lot of the pages are shredded or torn out. And I probably missed some of the torn pages since the halves were on opposite sides of the wreck.”

“I thought it would be something like that.” Lysithea sighed sadly.

“I’m so sorry!” Annette appeared suddenly, apologizing. She had been delayed by Lorenz who asked her if she would help keep Lysithea’s feet warm with her fire spell. It took a moment to dissuade Lorenz before she could get up the stairs. “I’m sorry the book got destroyed! I hope it’s not too much of a problem.”

“Why are you two apolgizing to me? It’s my fault for casting the spell in the first place, you don’t have to apologize.” Annette sighed in relief and nodded. Caspar looked at Leonie incredulously, which she silent waved off dismissively.

Moments later, Claude wandered up and greeted everyone. “Hey guys! Do any of you know what the heck Lorenz is doing?”

“I’d rather not talk about it.” Lysithea answered flatly.

Claude shrugged. "Fine by me.”

“Claude, did you figure out what we’re going to do next?” Ignatz asked.

“Indeed I did. After we gave up on finding a beanstalk for Lysithea to climb up. The leaders of the three houses came to an agreement.”

14531.title: Art Boi

choices: The red paint had a "G" on it, and Ignatz begins to grow.
The red paint had an "S" on it, and Ignatz begins to shrink.
The cap gets lost before he can see the letter. Either way, nothing happens yet.
145312.content:
(Takes place before the time skip, but after Ignatz has had many of his C and B support conversations. Spoilers should be minimal.)

After taking a deep breath of fresh air and wiping the fog from his glasses created by the early morning dew, Ignatz took a moment to admire the view as the sun rose, lighting the outer walls of the monastery and the forests surrounding it. He found a relatively dry log to sit on and brought out his satchel of art supplies.

His reasons for being out so early were twofold. First, the sunrise made an excellent subject for his next painting. Second, and most importantly, he still felt the need to keep his hobby a secret from the others. While Professor Byleth and anyone else that happened to discover his love of art never seemed to have a problem with it- in fact, many of his housemates had even encouraged him- he still couldn't shake the fear that someone would report to his father that he was wasting time painting instead of training to be a knight.

It was because of this fear that he had to buy his art supplies in secret. His most recent purchase, acquired during his free day last week once he was able to shake Raphael and his constant ill-advised attempts to rekindle their childhood friendship- was a strange set of paints offered by an enthusiastic but somewhat off-putting woman named Anna, who offered the paints at a steep mark-up because she claimed they had "mystical properties in battle."

Ignatz sincerely doubted that. However, he was out of paint, and couldn't order supplies by mail for fear that his father would find out. So, he was now the proud owner of a set of ridiculously overpriced "mysterious battle paint."

He examined the bottles. They seemed to be perfectly normal paints with a respectable variety of colors. The only thing unusual was that some of the bottles had a "G" inscribed on the cap while others had an "S."

"Must have something to do with the pigment," Ignatz mused. "Though I can't think of what those letters might mean. I guess I'll just have to experiment with them and find out."

He opened the red bottle first, planning to start with the pinks in the sky. Unfortunately, the top of the bottle was loose, and as soon as he tried to open it, the paint spilled out all over him. Cursing quietly to himself as the paint seeped through his clothes and made contact with his skin, he gave the bottle a closer look...
145312.title: Never Buy from Anna's Cursed Art Supply Emporium

choices: Leonie sits down with the book, giving Ignatz a chance to get her attention.
Leonie begins training, unknowingly endangering Ignatz in the process.
One of the knights comes to help train Leonie, giving Ignatz even more trouble.
1453122.content:
(Spoilers for Chapter 5)

Just as he registered the letter "S" engraved on the bottle of paint that had spilled all over him, Ignatz hunched over as he felt an intense sensation of vertigo.

Oh no... were those paints somehow meant for battle after all? Have I been poisoned?!

He collapsed on the ground, almost the verge of passing out when the pain and disorientation suddenly disappeared as quickly as they came. Still breathing heavily from the intense experience, he slowly got to his feet. Once he got a good look at his surroundings, his heavy breathing quickly turned to hyperventilation. Wet blades of grass surrounded him, almost taller than the trees he'd been surrounded by earlier. As he turned around, he saw a gigantic wooden wall several yards away that seemed to stretch almost as high as the walls of the monastery.

Craning his neck up to the top of is, he saw a corner of his impossibly giant sketchbook.

"How... how is this possible?!"

After several long moments of freaking out, Ignatz finally took a deep breath. Remembering Professor Byleth's lectures on tactics, he thought about his situation objectively.

"This happened immediately after I spilled paint on myself. What was different about it?" He snapped his fingers. "That's right! There were S's and G's on the bottles. Let's see... the one I spilled had an S on it... that must stand for 'shrink!' If the other one stands for 'grow,' that should grow me back!"

He looked up to the giant wooden log his supplies were on top of.

"Well... it's a long climb that my muscles really aren't built for... but I guess I have no choice but to..."

Ignatz was cut off by an ominous hiss behind him. He turned and shrieked as he saw a gigantic field mouse, roughly the size of the beast Mikan had turned into during the Golden Deer's last mission. It opened its mouth to hiss again, its sharp teeth clearly capable of snapping Ignatz in half.

"AAAHHH!" Ignatz fled. With a snarl, the mouse chased after him.

"Why are you chasing me?!" Ignatz demanded desperately as he wove around blades of grass to evade the giant furry beast and its bites. "You don't even eat meat!" The tiny artist was so focused on the chase that he didn't notice the thundering booms in the distance gradually getting closer and closer, until finally a gigantic black boot slammed into the wet earth in front of them.

As the mouse squeaked in terror and fled, its meal forgotten in the presence of this much larger creature, Ignatz craned his neck up to get a look at his unwitting savior. The boots gave way to socks, which gave way to two relatively thin legs, one with a knee guard on it. The legs disappeared into a school skirt with a recognizable orange sweater tied around it.

"IGNATZ?"

"L-Leonie?" Ignatz muttered as he finally got a look at his classmate's face. He'd hoped her calling out his name meant she saw him, but no, she was simply looking around the forest, expecting to find him at normal size.

"Strange... his art supplies are here..."

With that, she took a step towards the log, her massive feet creating craters in the muddy earth. Ignatz swallowed. Seeing his friend dwarf him so imposingly finally drove home just how tiny he was and how much danger he was truly in. He needed to get her help before something happened to him.

---

Leonie made her way to her usual training spot in the woods outside the monastery at the crack of dawn, a training bow and spear strapped to her back. She was up early to get in some last minute training because today, she was going to demand Professor Byleth spar with her and not take no for an answer. Maybe if she did well it would impress Captain Jeralt.

Once she reached the clearing, her eyes brightened as she spotted a familiar satchel and art book on a nearby log. Ignatz must be out here, she thought, looking around in hopes of greeting her friend before getting started. Not seeing him anywhere nearby, she frowned in confusion.

"Ignatz?" She called out. "Strange... his art supplies are here..."

Unaware of the fact that she had just saved her classmate from a strangely carnivorous mouse, she walked towards the art supplies. "He wouldn't have left them here... would he?"

She sighed in concern as she remembered what Ignatz had said the last time they talked about his art.

So my art won't do anyone any good. At all. Ever.

"Oh, Ignatz..." Leonie muttered sadly as she approached the supplies. One of the paint bottles was broken, the red paint already dried where it had spilled on the log. She took the rest of it and packed it into the satchel as carefully as she could, and decided to keep an eye on it while she trained. If Ignatz came back for his supplies while she was here, great. If not, she'd take them back to the monastery and give him a talking to.

"Hmm..." Leonie mused as she finished putting away the paint and eyed Ignatz's book. "Now that I think about it, I've never actually seen his work..."

151311.content:
The hardest part of watching someone you love grow up was letting them go. However, as Flayn’s growth had been stunted at roughly six or so centimeters tall, Seteth had an excuse to never let her out of his sight. This led to the green haired tiny to live a sheltered life, one she hated.

However, even his diligent watch wasn’t enough to keep her safe. Flayn had a habit of running off and exploring the world at her size, leading to a few close calls involving everything from almost being stepped on, sat on, and even a few occasions of nearly being eaten. The green haired girl couldn’t resist sampling slices of cake several times as tall as she was.

However, that was nothing compared to her kidnapping at the hands of the Death Knight. Thankfully, she was rescued by Byleth and their students, leading Seteth to finally trust in the new Professor. Which is why he called them to a meeting over tea.

Flayn hugged a cookie and gnawed into it with no remorse as her caretaker nervously took a drink from his tea. His nerves were soothed as he took in the taste of Angelica tea. Surely if the Professor was conscientious enough to procure his favorite brew, then she’d be the right person to watch over Flayn.

“What do I owe the pleasure?” Byleth asked, taking a sip from her own cup.

“It’s about Flayn,” Seteth began. He looked down at her and sighed. With his free hand, he wrestled the cookie out from her grip, earning a few hisses from the shrunken student. He ignored it as he broke it into much more manageable pieces for her to tear into. “I fear she is no longer safe under my watch alone.”

“Ah,” Byleth hummed simply, appreciating him getting to the point. “I suppose you want me to watch over her.”

Seteth nodded. “Yes. More importantly…”

“I want to be a part of your class!” The tiny girl chirped, her face and hair covered in a layer of crumbs and sugar.

Byleth pursed their lips, a subtle show of emotion they never recalled having before.

Ha! That little pipsqueak? Snarked a voice from the deepest recesses of her mind. She’s barely fit to clean the dirt from your nails.

“I know what you’re thinking,” Seteth interjected. “However, my dear Flayn is rather adept at magic. Overwhelmingly so, actually. I’d like you to hone her talents, and teach her some Reason spells for self defense.”

“Can I learn fire spells, brother?”

“Absolutely not.” He turned to the professor. “I think wind spells would suit her best.”

Byleth nodded. “I’m honored that you would trust me to take Flayn into my care. I’ll protect her as if she were my own.”

“That’s reassuring to hear,” Seteth said, finally letting out an exhale. “I’d like to check in with her every once in a while, but I trust that she will be safe in your hands.”

“Of course.”

“And one more thing,” Seteth began. “Please make sure she doesn’t wander off. She tends to land herself in some precarious positions if she’s left unattended.”

The professor nodded again as she set her hand down on the table. On cue, Flayn clambered onto Byleth’s palm, sitting crosslegged in the center. She nibbled on a chunk of cookie the size of her head.

I take it back! Sothis cooed. Protect that precious wittle child with your life or I will smite you!

Seteth let out a sigh as he stretched a finger out to pat Flayn’s head. “Stay safe, Flayn.”

“I’ll make no promises,” she said back with a giggle.

Byleth cautiously stood up from the table, making sure not to disorient her new charge. “Come now, little one. Let me formally introduce you to the rest of your fellow…”

15221.content:
(Set during month 10/ Chapter 7. No spoilers. Also, Shamir and Catherine are the best pairing. Fight me.)

Shamir really needed to stop making bets with Catherine. At first, the prizes were small. Loser pays for drinks. Minor stuff like that. However, the two quickly got bored and found ways to raise the stakes on each other.

This time, as Shamir found herself centimeters tall at the feet of the blonde knight, she was beginning to feel these bets weren't all that good of an idea. She was confident she would win, but Byleth apparently preferred Catherine, handing over the whetstone and settling their petty bet.

"Hey there, little lady," Catherine boomed obnoxiously.

An earpiercing scratching forced the mercenary to cover her ears as Catherine's boots slightly shifted on the ground when she squatted down to get a good look at her new prize. She grinned, thinking of all the ways she could exert her power over Shamir.

The tiny knight stared up at the incomprehensibly massive figure above her. Her knees went weak. Although, she didn't quite know why.

Sure, her partner was attractive, and they certainly had intimate nights together on long journeys to missions with nothing but each other. However, Catherine was also brash and thickheaded, something she didn't value in people. Though, as Shamir quickly came to realize, she put a lot of value into strength.

And at this size, Catherine was the most powerful thing in the world to her.

That fact was quickly made obvious as the blonde plucked her partner high into the air to meet her face while also standing up. This led to a gut churning pressure as the g-forces pressed down onto Shamir thanks to the movement. Even then, Catherine's powerful fingers held an impossibly strong grip on her, reminding the tiny knight just how helpless she was to her partner's every whim.

"Oh, the things I could do to you," Catherine said with a husky tone. She rubbed her thumb over Shamir's body, enjoying the feeling of her squirming in her fingers. She made sure to press her thumb between Shamir's legs, chuckling at how her tiny prize instinctually closed her legs around the digit.

The reserved mercenary let out an involuntary moan through grit teeth. She wasn't about to give her the satisfaction, yet a part of her wanted to be toyed with. She was manhandled easily with just two of Catherine's fingers, and there was nothing she could do in her power to stop it. The worst part was that she wanted more of it.

This was supposed to be a humiliating punishment, but why was she into it?

Catherine pulled her thumb away, only to be surprised to see the tiny woman desperately clinging onto her. "Bit excited there, aren't you, Shamir? Don't worry, we'll have a lot of time together."

She was right. The punishment would last until the end of the month.Until then, she was just Catherine's plaything, something she dreaded until just a few moments ago. Now, she wondered just how Catherine would have her way with her.

The blonde brute loosened her armor, letting her breastplate hang loose as she used her free hand to pry open her collar. She brought Shamir up to the gap, chuckling to herself before letting go and letting the purple haired knight tumble down into the dark canyon waiting below her.

Losing all sense of direction but down, Shamir slid across the giantess' skin, which was slick with sweat despite the cool wind of the Wyvern Moon. It didn't take long for her to be wedged between Catherine's hulking breasts. What little air there was smelled of stale Catherine. Her face and upper body was spread eagle across the top of the giant blonde's breast, which was surprisingly spacious up until the point where Catherine tightened her breastplate, flattening the tiny knight.

Shamir let herself get lost in the hazy heat. The way her body had been splayed out was like she was hugging the massive hills, something she didn't know she wanted until now. She rested her head against Catherine's soft skin, deciding to enjoy her time here while it was still private.

Catherine cannot know I'm into this.

Once light and Catherine's fingers returned, Shamir found herself...
15221.title: In Which Shamir Awakens to a Size Kink

choices: It's Byleth and Manuela, and they've brought a deck of cards.
It's Byleth and some of their students, and they've brought a board game.
152213.content:
With both a surprising amount of delicate balance and a not-so-surprising amount of sheer speed, Shamir was plucked out of her personal heaven. She was immediately thankful for the crisp fall air she could breathe now, and yet she already found herself pining for the heat she had been ripped away from. Once again, Shamir found herself held in the air at a height most people would find dizzying, although her attention was anywhere but the ground below her, as Catherine leaned so close that Shamir could likely reach out her arm to touch the tip of their nose.

"I bet you enjoyed yourself in there?" Catherine asked, giving a hearty laugh as Shamir, despite their best efforts, failed to hide the blood rushing to her cheeks. "Relax! Here, let me set you down for now."

The giant's hand gave a swift descent (threatening to send Shamir's lunch of spicy fish and turnip stew straight back up) and the herculean fingers unpinched, letting their catch drop a relative few feet onto a wide wooden surface.

Now that her vision and attention wasn't dominated by Catherine, Shamir's keen senses could take stock of her new surroundings. She had already acertained that she was on a barren table, as she noticed the once-small knicks and dents that were no doubt dug by copper coins and sharp nails belonging to idle daydreaming students, now magnified to exemplify how tiny she was. Beyond the mesa of wood, there was a wall that rivaled the cathedral in height, but instead of stonework and stained glass, it was row after row of books. In the distance to the 'south', a fireplace akin to a forest inferno sizzled in its pit. Benches were lined around the gigantic room, some seated near the aforementioned fireplace while others had been lined up by the table. A desert of grey stone awaited below, while the sky was now replaced with dark wood. Most humans would fail to see much beyond that, but Shamir's eagle-eyed vision could even spot the bulletin board and training dummies across the vast distance to the other end of the hall, and her hearing picked out the calls of crickets and owls beyond the doorway that seemed fields away to her now.

"This is the Knight's Hall," Shamir announced, certain in her deduction. She craned her head to look up at Catherine, who was looking back down with a telltale smile on her face. While Shamir had acclimated to her new stature far quicker than most likely would, it was still humbling - and quite exhilarating - to see her fellow knight looming over her, radiating raw power without so much as saying a word. It took Shamir a second or two to stop staring into Catherine's eyes and finish her thought. "I hope you're not planning to show me off to the other knights." Shamir dreaded the thought of bearing with Alois at a scale where his abundant energy could be more than a little detrimental.

Catherine gave a laugh, deep and boisterous enough that Shamir could swear that she felt the table itself shake (or maybe it was just her knees again.) "Of course not! If it were up to me, I'd have you all to myself right now!" Shamir angled her head away, aware of the blush returning to her face and now astute enough to hide it behind her hair. "But you see, I didn't really think I'd win our wager. The professor usually tends to play you as their favorite, after all."

She wasn't wrong - Shamir had noticed that Byleth had invited them to tea more than once this month, while Catherine had been left conspicuously absent. Then again, Shamir thought to herself, Catherine isn't exactly the best when it comes to teatime etiquette.

"Since I didn't expect this little present of mine-" Catherine made sure to emphasize her wordplay with a lick of the lips, and Shamir somehow felt even smaller than before. "-I'd already made plans for tonight. I just blocked out the hall for a private game between some friends and I, and it's a bit too late for me to cancel all of a sudden."

"I see," Shamir said, walking closer to the folded arms of Catherine on the edge of the table. In their steel bracers, they looked more like mighty metal pillars that had fallen atop one another. "What's the game? No more wagers, I hope."

Catherine gave a low mirthful chuckle as the hand nearest to Shamir drummed its fingers in mock thought, causing the archer to brace so that she might not be tripped over. Shamir bit her lip - even the slightest tremors of Catherine's most idle of movements exuded power. "We'll see - we're just waiting for our guests to arrive. You will be joining in, right? It'll be fun, promise!"

Shamir nodded, allowing herself a faint smile. This wasn't exactly the evening she had planned, but it was still an interesting situation and... Well, for whatever else she wanted to try, she had the rest of the month left anyway. "Of course. It's not like I could say no, after all."

"No," Catherine said, flashing her teeth at her shrunken partner. "You're mine."

Despite their difference in size and being considerably distracted at the moment, Shamir was the first to hear the sound of footsteps in the distance, as Catherine's intended party entered the Knight's Hall.
152213.title: The Game Knight

choices: Catherine, who happily takes her prize back to her room.
Manuela, who is in desperate need of relief, which Shamir can supply.
Byleth, who has more than enough ideas for what to do with a tiny Shamir.
1522131.content:
Shamir was just as awestruck to see the Catherine's guests enter the Knight's Hall. Even in the distance, she knew they were titans compared to her. They only commanded more of her vision as they stepped up to the table, each carrying something that wouldn't lead to anything good.

Professor Manuela, seemed to be fanning herself with a spread out deck of cards as she made a remark about how stuffy the Knight's Hall always was. To her left, Professor Byleth carried a cask of what Shamir presumed to be ale. The barrel had to have a small sea's worth of alcohol that would almost certainly be greedily imbibed by the three.

She couldn't help but wonder just what would the professor's reaction be once the Catherine inevitably let the reason why she shrunk slip. Even as stoic as the professor was, she had to at least raise an eyebrow or something. Maybe her new size could make perception subtle changes in Byleth's expression easier.

"Right on time," Catherine said, leaning back in her own seat as the others joined her. She kicked her feet up on the table, making sure to drop her boots dangerously close to Shamir.

Noticing the dropping shadow, Shamir jumped out of the way from her giant partner's incoming boot that nearly crushed her into a paste. The crash shook her to the inside of her bones, almost rattling her had she not seen it coming. She stared up at the wall of leather, eying pebbles trapped in the treads far larger than she was. Once again, the experience of feeling as small as the dirt beneath Catherine's feet was breathtaking.

It wasn't until the screeching of chairs sliding that Shamir turned her attention away from her giant partner. She was in the presence of two more giants, both of which unaware of her current size.

Manuela dropped the cards on the table and proceeded to shuffle them. The simple act of the cards flipping and interlocking was enough to send gale force winds racing towards the near minuscule Shamir. However, the tiny knight planted her feet and held her ground as the man made storm nearly swept her off her feet in both a literal and figurative sense.

Even Manuela's not looking too bad down here...

Byleth dropped the cask onto the table and began to pour drinks out. The impact was more than enough to startle Shamir, who felt the quakes tenfold. She fell to her knees and planted a palm on stable ground, keeping her steady.

"Careful there," Catherine hummed, her concern insincere. "You almost crushed my plus one."

"What do you mean?" Manuela asked.

Catherine pulled her hand out from resting behind her head and pointed to the speck by her boot. Manuela leaned forward to get a better look, her half-exposed chest resting on the table and giving the tiny knight an enticing view of a valley she wouldn't mind traversing.

"Sh-Shamir!?" Manuela asked, her eyes wide. "What happened?"

"Lost a bet," Shamir answered flatly, raising her voice to be heard.

Byleth glanced at Catherine as she slid over a filled glass of ale. "Did this have anything to do with the whetstone?"

"Yep!" Catherine answered, another grin forming. "Why did you choose to give it to me?"

Byleth shrugged. "Petra needed a new sword."

Catherine let out a laugh at the answer before taking a swig from her mug. "Hear that, Shamir?"

"As if I couldn't," Shamir said flatly. While she was certainly annoyed at the answer combined with her partner's gloating, a part of her was a bit glad she discovered whatever this was about herself. Depending on how the rest of this month went, she wouldn't mind losing more bets like this.

"Enough smalltalk," Catherine cut off, emphasizing the word 'small.' "You gals ready?"

The two nodded as Manuela began dealing the hand. Shamir merely watched, quickly picking up that they were playing poker. A few rounds went by with either Catherine and Manuela taking the win with early folds from the others. Nothing notable really happened until Byleth took up and contested Catherine's bluff.

"For someone with the best poker face in the world," the blonde knight said while wiping her lips with her sleeve. "You're pretty terrible at it."

Byleth didn't protest or even look upset when she began to shed off her coat.

So they're playing that kind of poker... Shamir thought, her face heating up. Explains why they're not throwing gold around.

As the rounds went on, Byleth continued to shed clothes, unconcerned that she was without a top only two hands later. All the while, the three got looser with more glasses of alcohol draining from the cask. Eventually, through a drawing of unfortunate cards, Catherine had lost the next round.

The blonde knight smirked as she looked at the others, who were expectantly waiting for her to shed some clothes. "Well, Shamir? They're waiting."

The blush returned to the knight's face. "Wait. What?"

"You heard me," she said. "You have to do whatever I want, remember."

"Fine..." Shamir rolled her eyes as she slid off her jacket.

"Gotta give 'em more skin than that," Catherine commanded, the faintest hint of a slur in her voice. "Take your top off."

Shamir bit her lip but did as she was told, removing the tight shirt and standing there with only her bra covering her upper body.

Catherine whistled, causing Shamir's blush to deepen.

As the rounds went on, Shamir began to suspect that her parter was intentionally throwing rounds. She forced off her boots and socks with each losing hand. The only thing keeping her from going completely in the nude was Byleth's terrible play. All this combined, left Manuela (who had only taken off her white fur shawl) feeling a bit frustrated at her lack of action in general.

Manuela groaned as she slammed down her glass against the table, startling Shamir. "It'sh not fair!" she cried to no one in particular. "Why do I have to be attracted to men? At times it seems like not a single member of the opposite sex is interested in me whatsho-ever."

Catherine chuckled. "If it's any consolation, I think you're hot. Me and Shamir would be happy to show you that you don't need a man in your bed to leave you satisfied."

Shamir stared up at the two women, who were both clearly loosened up by their drinks, and shuddered at the thought of taking part in a drunken, sloppy threesome with them at her size. Even then, she wasn't entirely sure if the chill came from fear or excitement. Or perhaps the cold, considering she was now down to her smallclothes.

"As lovely as that propo-zishun sounds," Manuela began, her voice still a drunken purr. She leaned over to Byleth and cupped one of her massive, half-exposed breasts before jiggling it. "This does absolutely nothing for me."

Byleth didn't protest. In fact, she didn't even say anything at all. Her eyes were still focused on her own cards. The new Professor's absolute indifference to Shamir's new size drove the tiny knight just as wild as seeing Catherine lord over her. She definitely wouldn't mind spending the night with her and exploring the mountains that Manuela was taking for granted.

Steel yourself, Shamir scolded, standing there awkwardly.

Catherine yawned. "Gettin' kinda tired here." She thumbed through her hand, seeing potential in her cards. "Let's make things interesting."

Oh no... Shamir thought, noticing the glint in Catherine's eye. It was the same one she saw when the blonde brought up the bet where the loser took a shrinking potion.

"One last hand," she said. "Whoever wins gets to take Shamir home for the night."

Shamir turned to her current owner. "Catherine, you can't—"

"Yes I can," she snapped back. "It was in the bet. Besides, I've seen you staring. You wouldn't mind this at all, wouldn't you?"

Shamir stared down at her feet, hating that Catherine was right.

"I'm down," Byleth said, an equally competitive look in her eyes. Shamir could only imagine the kinds of things Byleth would do to her if she were at her mercy.

Manuela took in the last drops of her drink. "I dunno..."

Catherine grinned. "Think of all the places you can put her to let out your frustrations."

At this point, Shamir's bottom lip was bitten raw.

"What do you get from this?"

"Simple," Catherine said. "I get the satisfaction of taking a prize I've won twice over home. And when I do..." She leaned closer and loomed over Shamir, getting right in the tiny knight's personal space. The alcohol in her breath was absolutely overwhelming. "I'm gonna stick her where the sun don't shine."

"C-Catherine!" Shamir protested, the teasing becoming a little too excruciating as her voice came close to a squeal.

Catherine only grinned, leaning back in her seat. "So?"

"I suppose, I could try experimenting," Manuela hummed, her own ideas coming to mind spurred by Catherine's thoughts.

"Great," she hummed. "Show your cards, everyone."

Shamir's heart was racing as she watched everyone reveal their hands. At this point, she didn't care who it was, she just wanted to go with someone to end the merciless teasing. She studied the table, quickly realizing with excitement that the winner was...

152331.content:
Captain Jeralt Reus Eisner had seen many strange things in his life as a warrior, but nothing could have prepared him for something like this. The re-recruited captain of the Knights of Seiros had somehow shrunken over night. If he had to guess he would say he was about 1/2 an inch in height, a mere bug.

How had this happened too him? Was he exposed to something? Or perhaps more than likely he was being targeted. It wouldn't really surprise him honestly. It wouldn't be the first time someone tried to kill him, and the monastery had a history of being infiltrated before. Even still, this was a rather... Unique way of getting rid of him.

In a normal fight he could pretty best any would be assassin out for his blood, so it made sense that his assailant would want him at a severe disadvantage. In his current state all it would take to kill him was one well misplaced stomp. But thankfully for him the halls of Garreg Mach were currently empty.

He was all alone. So that begged the question... Why was he still alive? Where was his attacker? Why haven't they revealed themselves? He was vulnerable and there were no witnesses currently. So why not snuff him out now while they could get away with it? It didn't make sense to just leave him to wonder about unless...

Oh his executioner had twisted sense of humor. They must have left him be so that any unsuspecting student or knight could crush him flat without notice. What a cowardly way to dispose of an enemy. They would rather sit and watch instead of getting their own hands dirty. How low could one get?

Well, Jeralt guessed it didn't matter now. He might as well use his secret assassin's hubris to his advantage. He needed to get noticed so he could get some help. Lady Rhea with all of the vast resources at her disposal could definitely find a cure for his condition. That is... If he got noticed.

He still had to be careful. His would be assassin could change their mind at any time and snuff him out whenever they wished. Then there were the students and knights. They could easily mistake him for a bug and crush him. That wouldn't be pleasant. He would have to be doubly cautious.

"Alright. It's time to get a move on." Jeralt told himself. It was time to get moving. There was no sense in staying stationary.

15311.content:
(Takes place pre-time skip, sometime between Chapter 6 and 7. Minor spoilers.)

Tonight, Byleth was regretting several of his life choices.

It had started with constantly finding lost items and returning them to the students. Then he started doing random odd jobs and favors for anyone who'd ask whenever he had a free day. Then he started replying to requests for advice in the confession box. He tried to be anonymous, but apparently, his handwriting was distinct enough that everyone knew it was him.

Before Byleth knew it, he had become the go-to professor whenever students needed help or advice, whether they were part of his house or not. Sometimes it was rewarding, like when he got the likes of Marianne, Felix, or Bernadetta to actually participate in school activities and interact with their fellow students voluntarily. Sometimes it was terrible, like the night that Dimitri came to his room at three in the morning on behalf of Sylvain, who, in the words of the befuddled prince, "put it in a scabbard this time, and now it's stuck."

Tonight hadn't reached that level of unpleasantness yet, but was rapidly coming close.

"You... yoooooouuuuu're the besht, Professhor," Manuela slurred her words as she drunkenly leaned into the stoic younger professor. "Byleth'sh good people. Dorothea! Ishn't Byleth good people?"

"Yes, he sure is, Manuela. We're lucky we ran into him tonight," Dorothea dutifully answered her former opera costar and mentor as she put one of the drunk woman's arms around her shoulder and mouthed yet another "sorry" to Byleth.

"It's fine, Dorothea," Byleth assured her as he took Manuela's other arm and helped the Black Eagle half-walk, half-drag her to her quarters. "Let's just get her inside before someone else sees..."

"Ah," a somewhat pompous voice said. "Good evening, Professor Byleth," Hanneman greeted Byleth as he left the dining hall. "I was unaware that you were also on partrol tonight..."

He trailed off and sighed in disgust as he saw Manuella. "Oh, you must be joking. Really, Manuela? And so soon after your run-in with the Death Knight? Your wound so easily could have reopened from all your gallivanting about!"

"Oh no!" Manuela's head jerked up as she glared lazily at her rival. "Watch out, Byleth! Hanna... Hammerman'sh got a case of the stickbutt! You'll catsch it if you exshpose your butt to him! Trusht me... I'm a doctor... You should expose your butt to meeee..."

"There are all manner of things wrong with what you just said!" Hanneman huffed indignantly. "First of all..."

"Professor, please," Byleth said, tilting his head meaningfully towards Dorothea. "Not now."

Hanneman took a deep breath. "Yes... it is inappropriate to discuss this in front of a student. Very well, Professor. I will leave her in your hands. Are you still available for me to study your crest tomorrow?"

"Sure, why not?" Byleth agreed offhandedly, already working with Dorothea to put as much difference between Manuela and Hanneman as possible before the drunken songstress could provoke another argument.

"Your butt'sh forfeit Byleth... I waarrrrrrrned yooooouuuu..." Manuela slurred as she reached under Byleth's cloak and pinched his rear end. Byleth's eyes widened slightly but he otherwise did not react.

"Manuela, please," Dorothea sighed tiredly. "You're better than that. No offense, Professor."

"Mmmm you're a good, Dorothea. You're... mmm..."

Manuela went slack, passing out with an undignfied snore.

"Well, that simplifies things," Byleth declared. "Come on, Dorothea. Let's get her to her room before something else happens..."

"Professor!" Lysithea called out. spotting Byleth as she was leaving the library and running up to meet him. Byleth's eye twitched.

"You are certainly popular tonight, Professor," Dorothea joked lightly. Manuela grumbled incoherently.

"Claude and I have been working on our plan for the Battle of Eagle and Lion!" Lysithea announced excitedly, holding up a small bottle. "We were able to produce the effects to a potion instead of a spell, and..." she trailed off as she finally noticed that Byleth wasn't alone.

"Not a great time, Lysithea," Byleth gently scolded her. "We'll discuss it after class tomorrow, alright?"

"Good point, professor," Lysithea nodded before glaring at Dorothea. "We don't want to discuss things in front of the enemy. And Edelgard better not learn of any of this!"

"Don't worry, Lysithea," Dorothea smiled indulgently. "I have bigger things to worry about tonight. Your secret's safe with me." She smirked. "But as much as I respect Professor Byleth... your house is going down, little girl."

"Do NOT treat me like a child..." Lysithea stomped towards Dorothea menacingly, only to slip and fall. The bottle in her hand was inadvertently flung into the air, where the loose top came off and the potion within splashed all over Manuela.

"Hmm... wassat?" Manuela woke from the sensation.

"Ugh... Manuela, you're so much heavier, all of a sudden," Dorothea grunted, now struggling to hold her mentor's weight.

Byleth and Lysithea's eyes widened. "Dorothea," Byleth said gravely. "Let go."

"Huh?"

Manuela's arms suddenly expanded to the size and weight of heavy tree branches, nearly pinning Dorothea before she managed to shake the limp professor off of her. Manuela hit the ground with a thud and a grunt, both of which were considerably louder than they should have been.

"Manuela, I'm so sorry, I..." Dorothea trailed off as she stared, slack-jawed at the sight before her.

Manuela was growing. Already, she was twice as large as normal, and the growth was showing no sings of stopping.

"What's happening to her?!" Dorothea demanded with a shriek.

"Our secret weapon!" Lysithea cried. "I've been working on it all month and now it's ruined!"

"Manuela," Byleth moved towards the professor's ear. She was already fifteen feet tall and the growth was accelerating rapidly. "Come on, we need to get you somewhere out in the open.

"Mmm... the groundsh comfy," Manuella sighed, damaging the stone walkway as she rolled onto her side. "Nighty-night..."

Manuela fell back asleep. Her body was now big enough that it was starting to rub against the north wall of the reception hall creating an ominous groan.

"What's going on out there?!" Seteth's voice demanded loudly from within. "What's blocking the archway?!"

"And now Professor Casagranda's butt has everyone trapped in the reception hall," Lysithea sighed.

"At least she's still outside," Byleth half-heartedly consoled his student.

"I'm going to get expelled for this..." Lysithea fretted.

"You SHOULD get expelled for this!" Dorothea snapped.

"No one's getting expelled!" Byleth insisted as he walked around the expanding body until he was in front of Manuela's sleeping face. She was now fifty feet tall. "Professor?"

The giantess grumbled a bit as she exhaled a gigantic, alcohol-laced breath onto Byleth.

“MANUELA!” Byleth shouted. “WAKE UP!”
15311.title: The Walk of Shame

choices: Manuela wakes up. Thinking it's a dream, she gets handsy with Byleth.
Pent up from a bad night and charged with Seteth's help, her hand drifts south..
153113.content:
As it turned out, the already massive songstress wasn’t done growing. Those caught on the ground began to back away as her every expanding body began to hog up every inch of available space north of the reception hall. Her legs easily broke through the narrow walls that contained courtyards and the amusingly named Amiibo Gazebo.

Byleth dove out of the way of her growing legs as they nearly ran over him. Her heel, now as thick of a tree, would have impaled him had he not had the foresight to get out of the way. He grabbed Lysithea’s arm, moving her to the grassy courtyards and taking shelter under said hilariously named gazebo. Dorothea rushed over as well, and the three watched as Manuela grew to be the largest thing in Garreg Mach.

“There goes our big surprise,” Lysithea commented lamely. “Claude can break the bad news to Hilda.”

Dorothea blanched. “You were going to use this on Hilda? Honestly, Professor, out of all the Deer—”

“It’s a learning experience,” Byleth said, nonchalant, while also refusing to elaborate further on his thought process. “Lysithea, how long would it take to try to brew a cure?”

“It’s kind of late, Professor,” she said back.

The professor recognized the tone and sighed. “If you get it done tonight, I can excuse you from tomorrow’s seminar.”

“I really need to get my sleep if I want to grow taller, naturally, I mean. Plus, I like attending the seminars.”

“I’ll buy you the nicest cake I can find in town.”

Lysithea pumped her fists. “Consider it done.” The white haired mage rushed off from where she came, invigorated by the promise of cake.

Now that there was a way to reverse this issue on the way, Byleth’s next course of action was damage control and making sure she didn’t incite any…

“Panic!” cried a voice near the stables. “Everyone! A demonic beast has infiltrated the monastery!”

“First of all, rude,” Byleth began, looking up at the slumbering form of the massive diva. Aside from the fact that she was a bit awkwardly hunched over from her new size, there was nothing about her resembling a monster. “Second, Dorothea, be a dear and quiet him up before he wakes up the whole monastery.”

“On it, Professor,” Dorothea said, rushing off towards the stable.

“What’s this I hear about a demonic beast!?” Seteth’s muffled voice called from the inside of the reception hall. “I’m going to try and break through this barrier.”

“It’s a false alarm,” Byleth answered. “And keep trying to bust through. Let me know how that works out for you.”

He could barely make out Seteth’s grunting from the other side of the archway. The professor didn’t really know how to break it to the holy figure that he was pressing himself into Manuela’s rear, but that would be a bridge he’d cross when he came to it.

“Mmmm,” the giantess sleepily moaned from high above. “Feelsh, gooooooood.”

That was way more information than Byleth was willing to learn right about now.
