1551.content:
(Takes place pre-time skip during the Golden Deer route, on a free day in Month 12 between the end of Chapter 8 and the Winter Ball. Expect spoilers accordingly.)

"Ugh... my head..."

Claude awoke- or, more accurately, was dragged into consciousness by the searing pain in his temples. He blinked several times, his blurry vision keeping him from being able to identify his surroundings. All he knew for sure was that his head hurt, the world was far too bright for his eyes, and that something smelled amazing... and yet, familiar.

"Where am I?" Claude groaned as he struggled to piece together how he got here... wherever this place was. "Last thing I remember... I was at the library researching relics... and I found... something..."

"Claude!" a deep voice called out in the distance. "Yo! Guys! I found Claude!"

Claude's vision and wits started to barely return to him as he spotted Raphael running towards him, followed closely by Ignatz and Lorenz.

"Hey guys," Claude waved to his housemates, wincing and barely opening his eyes in deference to his still present headache. "What's going on?"

"Have you gone blind?!" Lorenz balked, his normally snide voice containing a very noticeable undercurrent of panic that Claude had never heard from him before. "Look around you!"

Powering through the pain, Claude forced his eyes open and took his first proper look around since waking up. They were on a massive white plain that seemed to be made out of some kind of linen. Next to them was a massive porcelain structure hundreds of times their size. If he didn't know better, Claude would swear it was a giant tea cup.

He turned around. Looming far in the distance was a great tower stacked with what seemed to be enormous cookies and scones just before the great white plain seemed to end with an abrupt cliff drop. At this sight, Claude was finally able to place where he'd smelled this delicious smell before- from Professor Byleth's tea parties that she would hold for her students on their birthdays or if they had done well in class or battle, and occasionally for students in other houses that she was not-so-subtly trying to recruit.

"So, we're surrounded by giant food," Claude observed, deciding that he was having a fever dream and rolling with it. "Raphael, this has to be the best day of your life."

"It kind of is!" Raphael agreed cheerfully.

"The food's not giant!" Ignatz yelled. "We're..."

Ignatz was cut off as a loud boom echoed behind Claude. The other three looked up and began backing away with varying levels of fear. Swallowing nervously, Claude turned around, only to see a very familiar amulet surrounded by two of the largest breasts he had ever seen. He craned his neck up, and his jaw drop in shock as he took in the impossibly giant visage of Professor Byleth.

Her expressionless face framed by long green hair was visible in more detail than Claude had ever seen before. Her eyes were focused on the teacup next to them as she poured from an equally giant teapot, the normally quiet sound of the tea meeting the cup echoing like an oppressive waterfall.

"Teach!" Claude snapped out of his stupor and called up to her. "Hey! TEACH!"

"Don't bother," Ignatz sighed. "We all yelled to her when she was setting up the table. We're way too small for her to hear us."

As if to further prove his point, Byleth lifted the teacup and took a sip as if nothing was wrong in the world, completely oblivious to the tiny quartet watching her from the table.

"Hmmm," her voice echoed, lower and more sonorous with her giant size. "Not my favorite blend. It could use more sugar..."

Claude turned to the others. "Okay... any idea how this happened?"

"I was assuming this was one of your idiotic schemes gone awry," Lorenz said with a sneer. "I seem to recall an incident with a shrinking potion..."

"Nah," Claude shook his head. "It wouldn't have made us this small. Besides, I threw it out after what happened last time." He frowned as he considered the situation. "I hate to say it, but this must be someone trying to get rid of us. I mean, a lot of weird stuff has been happening, and creeps like Jeritza, Tomas, and that Flame Emperor guy keep getting into the monastery."

"And whether we plan to or not, Golden Deer keeps getting caught up in it," Ignatz said.

"And kickin' their butts," Raphael added.

"Yeah," Claude pointed to the two in agreement. "We're probably a thorn in a lot of people's sides. Which is awesome, but not when it leads to something like this..."

"CLAUDE!" a tiny, feminine voice called out from a great distance.

"Wait..." Claude looked around. "Was that..."

"I see the girls!" Ignatz exclaimed. "They're on the dessert tray!"

"Hey, good eye, Ignatz," Claude praised. Now that he was concentrating on it, he could see some of the female contingent of the Golden Deer trapped on the scones in the distance.

Scones that a normal sized person could come and eat at any moment. Claude frowned as the implications set in.

"Okay, that's not a great place for them to be. We need a plan. Lorenz, you..."

"It is a noble's duty to aid those in peril!" Lorenz interrupted, already running for the tray. "Fear not, ladies! I am coming to save you!"

"Lorenz, you ass..." Claude muttered as he pinched the bridge of his nose. "Okay, I guess Lorenz is going to save the girls, and I'm going to follow him to make sure he doesn't get crushed or eaten. You two get Teach's attention and let her know what happened."

"Wait," Raphael held up his hand. "How are we supposed to..."

"Good luck!" Claude took off after Lorenz. Ignatz continued to stare at the tower of food as Raphael put a hand on his shoulder.

"C'mon, Ignatz, I know you're worried about them, but those two have this. Let's figure out how to get the Professor to..."

"I can only see three of the girls from here," Ignatz noted worriedly. "I wonder where the fourth one is..."

"Ah," Byleth finally spoke again, a small smile gracing her features. "I'm glad you could join me."

"Thanks for inviting me, Professor," a second voice boomed as Byleth's normal sized guest sat at the other end of the table, directly within reach of the dessert tray.

"Oh no..." Ignatz muttered as he looked up at the giant face of...
1551.title: Tea Time of Terror

choices: Suddenly, Marianne grabs the scone Lysithea's stuck on.
Lysithea safely gets down. However, Byleth notices ants on the dessert plate.
Follow Raphael and Ignatz climbing up the professor.
15512.content:
(Minor hints for Marianne and Byleth’s A support. No major spoilers.)

As tough as Byleth normally was with her students, she was particularly soft with Marianne. The downtrodden girl seemed beat up by life, and the professor wanted to make things a bit easier for her outside of battle. Their tea times together were much more regular than her other students, mostly because she felt the need to check up on Marianne often. Her reasons were currently just minor suspicions, but she enjoyed these quiet moments, even if the blue haired girl wasn't much of a conversationalist.

"I think we found the fourth," Raphael said, stating the obvious.

"My goddess…" Ignatz gasped. "Marianne's so… big."

Marianne eyed the tea cup below her. The soft scent of lavender blend tea wafted through the air. It was always nice of the professor to go out of her way and brew her favorite. Her gaze then drifted towards the plate of scones. She has skipped lunch earlier, mostly because the line in the dining hall was bustling with people. It wouldn't hurt to grab a treat or two. After all, Professor Byleth had a habit of bringing too many treats. She’d just hate to see any of it go to waste.

For the ant-like Deer below, the irony was not lost on them that their meekest classmate and healer was the one currently threatening their lives. Marianne was more than intimidating at their current size, as she could easily kill them several times over without even thinking about it.

“H-hey, Leonie, stay put, you’re going to fall!” Lysithea nagged, rushing to the edge of the scone. A sense of vertigo washed over her as she looked over the steep cliff of flaky dessert.

“Nuh-uh!” Leonie shot back, scaling down the wall as if it were a mountain climb. “You can stay up there and get eaten, but I’m getting out of here.”

Hilda stepped up to the edge. “Ugh, this would be so much easier if my wyvern shrunk with me.” She knelt down and also began making her way down the baked good.

“Hey! Just where are you going!?” Lysithea cried, realizing that she would be the only one left stuck on the scone. She hesitated again as she gazed over the edge. It wasn’t that she disliked heights or anything, it’s just that her two crests, while making her magically gifted, also kept her physically feeble. She lacked the constitution and the strength to make it the whole way down. The last thing she wanted was to end up as a stain on a pristine porcelain plate.

Instead, she just decided to stay put at the top of the mountain and wait for help.

“I think it’s just lovely that you go out of your way to catch extra fish for the kittens around the monastery, Professor,” Marianne said. “They might be stray, but they deserve love and affection as well.”

The professor nodded, taking a sip from her own cup. She leaned forward as she placed it back down.

“Whoa, that might be the most I’ve heard Marianne speak,” Raphael commented. He was a bit too distracted to notice his massive professor’s chest coming straight towards him.

“Raphael, run!” Ignatz cried, turning around, and running from the encroaching shadow. The larger student did the same, surprisingly catching up to the archer and barely escaping being crushed under the professor’s generous bust.

The pair found themselves just inches away from the giant pair of breasts. They caught their breath, just glad that they hadn’t met their early end just yet.

Then Raphael got an idea. “Yo, Ignatz, we can climb her necklace thingy!”

Ignatz blanched. “Are—Are you sure, Raphael? W-wouldn’t the professor get mad if she finds us… on her chest”

Raphael sprung to his feet. “Nah, she’d understand,” he answered as he grabbed Ignatz’ arm and practically dragged the weaker boy over to the cloth hanging off the metal. “You’re gonna want to hold on.”

Ignatz did as he was told, gripping onto the pink fabric tightly as Byleth leaned back, lifting the two high in the air. His stomach jumped up into his chest, making it hard for him to breathe, and sending a nauseous sensation. He closed his eyes and gripped tighter, not even wanting to think about the fall from this height. If he didn’t die on impact, he would most likely land on her lap and get lost in her intricate leggings.

“I noticed that you like looking over the bridge,” Byleth said. “It’s quite a lovely view.”

Marianne looked down at her hands, watching as the drink in her hands shook slightly with her hands. “Um, yes… The view is... nice.”

Meanwhile, Claude and Lorenz continued their wild sprint across the dining table. Time was certainly of the essence as the pair of giant women above made small talk, letting the tea cool down. It wouldn’t be long before one of them decided to fill the gap of silence with a treat.

As much as I like the professor, I don’t think I’m going to go to another one of her tea parties ever again, Claude thought, his heart racing from his impromptu cardio session and the adrenaline kicking in. By the time the pair mad it to the dessert tray, Leonie and Hilda were roughly halfway down their climb.

“Are there any good books you’ve read recently?” Byleth asked, gently leading the conversation around her shy student’s interests. “I’ve been looking for something new.”

Marianne nodded, some light returning to her eyes. “I’m in the middle of one now. It’s about a long lost princess in Valentia.”

“It sounds wonderful,” Byleth said, lazily stirring the spoon around her cup. While the slight grinding noise was almost too quiet for her to notice, it was a loud, painful screech for the shrunken students down below.

“Gah, stop that, Teach!” Claude yelled, shielding his ears. He wasn’t sure if it was his ears ringing or the stirring spoon.

“She can’t hear you, genius!” Yelled a voice from above. The pair of boys looked up to find Lysithea still at the top of the scone mountain.

Claude cupped his hands over his mouth. “What are you still doing up there? Don’t tell me you’re also afraid of heights.”

“N-no!” Lysithea countered, unintentionally sounding like a child. “I just don’t want to fall.”

Leonie hit the ground first, jumping from just high enough to make a safe landing. Hilda followed suit.

“Catch me, Claude!” the pink haired girl called as she let go of the wall and free fell. The house leader simply let her hit the ground. “You dick!”

“Consider it payback for my first shrinking incident,” he said, helping her up after a quick laugh.

“H-hey, I’m still up here!” Lysithea called, getting everyone’s attention again.

"Just warp yourself down!" Claude yelled.

"I would if I could," she argued. "Don't make me warp you up here with me."
15512.title: Just Desserts

choices: Lysithea succeeds, and she and Leonie are warped safely back to the table.
Lysithea's aim is off. She and Leonie get lost somewhere on Marianne's body.
Lysithea fails. Into Marianne's mouth they go.
155121.content:
The silence that was commonplace between the taciturn teacher and her shy student was interrupted by a quiet growling sound. Marianne looked down towards her stomach, blushing self-consciously.

"Marianne," Byleth's brow furrowed in concern. "Have you been skipping meals again?"

"Just... just lunch today," Marianne admitted. "There were a lot of people in the dining hall. I was uncomfortable..."

Byleth resisted the urge to scold Marianne for not taking better care of herself. If her concerns about her student were warranted, she needed to make sure their tea times were as pleasant and comforting for her as possible. Instead, she offered a gentle smile.

"Why don't you help yourself to a scone, then? That's why I brought them, after all."

"Th-thank you, professor," Marianne nodded with a shy smile as she reached for the dessert tray.

---

Down on the plate, Marianne's ant-sized classmates began to panic as her long, tree-trunk sized fingers grasped the scone next to Lysithea's, bringing the hulking, sugary land mass into the air with absolutely no effort as it disappeared into Marianne's mouth, the sounds of her chewing echoing ominously above.

"Lysithea, seriously, you need to get off the cookie! Right now!" Hilda yelled to the young mage.

"I-I can't!" Lysithea cried. Between her fear of falling and the fear of what would happen to her if she didn't get off the scone in time, she was starting to cry. Her four friends below were deliberately not drawing attention to it.

"Just jump at this point!" Claude shouted. "I'll catch you!"

"Like you caught Hilda?" Lysithea sniped back.

"I will catch you, Lysithea!" Lorenz cut in front of Claude. "I give you my word!"

The young mage whimpered in fear, still paralyzed by the situation.

"These are delicious, professor," Marianne boomed as she swallowed the scone.

"It's a new recipe I got from Professor Manuella," said Byleth. "Please, have as many as you like."

"Oh, SCREW this!" Leonie exclaimed as she started to climb back up the sugary wall.

"Leonie, what the hell are you doing?!" Claude demanded.

"Just be ready to catch us both!" Leonie snapped.

During their last battle in Renue Village, Leonie had a clear shot at the Death Knight. Just as she shouted her challenge to him and drew her spear, Lysithea warped her away from the battle, then used her magic to knock the fearsome adversary from his horse and force him to retreat.

At the time, Leonie was furious. She was convinced that the young mage deliberately ruined her chance to show her skills in front of Captain Jeralt. However, after some time to reflect, as well as a firm dressing down from both Claude and Professor Byleth, Leonie was forced to admit that she had grossly overestimated her own skills. In fact, it was very likely that by pulling her from the battle, Lysithea saved her life that day.

As someone who detested debt more than anything, Leonie would not rest until she repaid the favor.

"L-Leonie?!" Lysithea blurted out as Leonie finished scaling the wall. "What are you doing?!"

"We're not leaving you behind, Lysithea," Leonie held her hand out to the younger girl. "Come on! We'll climb down together!"

"I-I-I can't!" Lysithea flinched away from her. Leonie growled in frustration and grabbed her anyway.

"Then hold onto me and don't look down!" she ordered. "Because we need to get off of here before... oh no... AHHHHH!"

The ground around them shook as five gigantic fingers closed in around it, and a strong downward wind forced the two girls to their knees as their sugary platform was lifted up at terrifying speed. Marianne had chosen their scone to eat next.

"Lysithea," Leonie gasped urgently as Marianne's face loomed ever closer, the massive healer completely unaware that she was about to devour two of her friends along with her sugary treat. "Lysithea, you have to do what Claude said. You have to warp us down!"

"The spell doesn't work that way!" Lysithea argued. "I can only bring people to me! I can't teleport!"

"Then MAKE it work that way!" Leonie began to tremble as Marianne opened her mouth. Thin cords of saliva dripped from the roof to the tongue as it stretched out slightly in anticipation of the sugary confection. Mushy remains of the previous scone were visible between her teeth, serving as a grim reminder of the fate that awaited them. "Lysithea, I don't know much about magic, but I know that you're the best mage at this academy! And it's not because of your second crest, it's because you're you! Now work your magic and save us just like you did in Renue Village!"

"I'll... I'll try!" Lysithea closed her eyes tightly, trying to ignore the oppressive feeling of Marianne's hot, humid breath washing over them as she focused on the table where Claude and the others were while channeling magic through her body...
155121.title: Repaying a Debt

choices: Dispose of some insects she had just found on the table
1551211.content:
Lysithea channels her magic ability and, in a sort of magical wonder, is able to keep her focus throughout the ensuing ordeal. As Leonie holds her tight, the young mage finally gets enough power channeled to warp them both to the safety of the table, finding themselves with there fellow deer

"I found them! They made it!" Claude yells to Hilda and the others while running towards the pair. Just as Claude and the others arrive to comfort their friends, Marianne's fingers seemingly slam into the table as she gets prepared to...
1551211.title: Lysithea succeeds, and she and Leonie are warpe...

choices: They're in one of Marianne's pockets.
They're in one of Marianne's shoes.
1551212.content:
Lysithea could feel the magical energy within - powerful, yet finite. To teleport both herself and someone else across a vast distance would be a monumental task, one that was practically impossible even for the best spellcasters in all of Fodlan. However, whether it was by the 'blessings' of her dual Crests, her months of training in the arcane arts, or just the sheer adrenaline when she felt darkness fall upon her as the scone finally passed through Marianne's lips, Lysithea von Ordelia did the impossible. The mage screamed in pain as she pushed beyond her limit, and in a puff of light, both Leonie and herself disappeared (just as their unaware classmate finally closed their jaw and bit into the scone.)

Unfortunately, it always took Lysithea the utmost concentration to use her warping spell. When she had saved Leonie from the Death Knight in their prior mission, she had thankfully been defended from any distractions or attacks, and she had focused clearly on the spot right in front of her with her own eyes. Suffice to say, being the size of a speck and filled with the dread that she might be turned into mush by her friend's teeth had been far more distracting for the mage. Now, as she and Leonie tumbled through the space between spaces for the briefest of moments, her thoughts of Claude and the others on the table were consumed by the gigantic Marianne that could have been their unwitting executioner. Consequently, it was all the spell needed for a destination.

Light, sound and air returned to the two girls as they were deposited back into the waking world, landing together in a crumpled heap.

Leonie groaned - it felt like their stomach had been flipped, turned inside out and then flipped again. "Uuuuugh..." Leonie took a few seconds to flex her limbs until the feeling returned to them before pushing herself back to her feet. She was more than a little dizzy, but patting herself down, she seemed intact, alive and not currently drowning in saliva or melting in stomach acid. "B-By the Goddess, you did it! Lysithea, you really did it! I knew you could-!"

Lysithea coughed up globules of blood in response.

"Oh, right... I guess that did a number on you, huh? Don't worry, I can take it from here..." Leonie quickly sought to return the favor, kneeling down and hoisting the borderline-comatose mage over their back, wrapping their thin arms around her shoulders so that they might carry them. Leonie was thankful that Lysithea was so short and light compared to her other classmates (although they were still slightly heavier than she would have expected for someone so frail - she chalked it up to all the sweets and desserts that they must have eaten as of late.)

"You good?" Leonie asked, turning her head to eye her piggybacking partner.

Lysithea mumbled something that vaguely sounded like an acknowledgement.

Leonie nodded, before turning to examine her surroundings, now that her senses were finally starting to return to her in earnest. "Now... Just where the heck are we anyway...?"
1551212.title: Destination: Anywhere But Here

choices: Lysithea and Leonie meet in the stomach and try to warp again.
Claude attempts to spike Marianne's drink. It doesn't go well.
Raphael and Ignatz continue to try to climb the Professor.
1551213.content:
Lysithea hugged Leonie tight. “I’m so sorry! I can’t do it!”

Biting her tongue, Leonie held her back. As often as she let her emotions get to her, the last thing Leonie wanted now was to say something she’d regret to her panicking friend before they met their end. “It’s okay, Lysithea. We’ll make it out of this… somehow.”

The white haired mage knew those words were only for comfort, but she didn’t care. She burrowed her head deeper into Leonie’s shoulder and shut her eyes. She wasn’t going to allow herself to have her last memories be of the chewed up mush inside her friend’s mouth.

Leonie, while not the most spiritual person, made silent prayers to the goddess as she was carried into the dark cave that took them in.

The tiny deer below watched in terror as two of their classmates disappeared into the depths of Marianne’s mouth. All that they knew of them, from their idle chatters to fighting at each other’s side was reduced to the sounds of chewing.

Hilda winced, feeling bile rise up to the back of her throat. Lorenz dramatically dropped to his knees while Claude stood stone faced, shocked by the sudden turn of events. For once, he was left with no idea of what to do. Even getting the Professor’s attention wouldn’t help unless she somehow had the power to turn back time.

“Maybe there’s a chance they’re still…” Claude trailed off. He hated relying on chance, but he hated not knowing what was going on even more. For all he knew they were simultaneously alive and dead. But it wouldn’t remain that long as Marianne continued to snack on the treat.

“I don’t see any way…” Lorenz didn’t finish either.

“Oh, Goddess, I’m gonna be sick,” Hilda groaned, joining Lorenz on her knees and clutching her stomach.

Claude’s eyes went wide, digging into a pocket and pulling out a bag of powder. “That’s it! All we need to do is spike Marianne's tea with my stomach poison. Hilda, you’re amazing! I could kiss you.”

Hilda threw up in response.

“But not right now.”

——

Any trace of light disappeared within the confines of the healer’s mouth as Marianne bit down. The sudden break, had sent the pair of tiny teenagers tumbling down. In the panic, they had let go of each other, quickly losing track of the other.

Lysithea got off relatively easier as she slowly slipped down the back of the massive tongue. She tried to claw onto anything to latch onto, but found nothing as she fell into a deep chasm, sliding down the already lubricated muscles that were Marianne’s throat.

Leonie, however, was much less lucky. She had managed to grab onto a crumb, one that had already been soaked in the giantess’ spit. However, that didn’t matter as it extended her chance to survive, giving her a buoy to hold onto in the lake like pools of saliva collecting in Marianne’s mouth.

She was thrown all around as she learned what it was like to be a piece of meat. She kept her grip tight embracing hits as she collided with Marianne’s molars. She wasn’t going to let herself get swallowed so easily. Unfortunately, it seemed everything conspired against her. The smelling the humidity was nauseating. The constant earthquakes threatened to throw her off.

She survived all that. However, it was not enough as her latest obstacle proved much too overwhelming to navigate.

Light flooded the inside of her mouth, giving the microscopic Leonie a view of the outside world. It was only a sliver, her lips barely parting, and the light diluted even more through the giantess’ massive teeth. However, it was just enough for Leonie to realize that Marianne was taking a drink.

A tidal wave of tea came flooding in, chasing after the shrunken knight in training. Leonie bolted up onto her feet and tried to run to find some sort of refuge. Unfortunately the near boiling tsunami came in at an unfathomable speed, sweeping her away and dragging her to the back of the giantess’ throat.

What was a destructive force of nature for Leonie actually was just a cursory sip of tea for the quiet mage. It was still much too hot to enjoy fully, but it did wash down the cookie rather well.
1551213.title: Washed Down

choices: Byleth leans down and blows them off of the table.
Byleth brings a finger down to crush them flat.
Marianne spots the 'ants' and interjects - she likes collecting insects.
155122.content:
Lysithea faltered at the edge of the flaky mesa for a moment longer, until a hand from the heavens descended to grab another one of the enormous snacks - the one just next to hers, in fact. She watched in a mixture of awe and terror as Marianne moved a mountain, hoisting it up and crunching into it with barely a waiver of effort.

The paralysis of indecision was over - even if she was likely to go careening down to the hard porcelain below, she’d rather die here than grinded to pulp between her friend’s incisors. Lysithea whimpered and finally pulled herself over the edge to begin her descent.

To her surprise and relief, the surface of the scone was not as difficult to scale as she had initially thought. Perhaps it was due to the sugary treat and its properties, or perhaps the adrenaline of the moment was simply pushing Lysithea beyond her limits. Then again, the professor had been tutoring her in the art of brawling recently. She had no earthly clue as to why, but if it gave her the arm strength to make her way down to relative safety, then she wouldn’t look the gift horse in the mouth. She didn’t want to think about mouths at all right now.

“Attagirl, Lysithea! You got this!” Leonie called out.

“Yeah, way to go!” Claude followed. Even now, his fellow students found new ways to surprise and impress him.

Lysithea continued to scramble down as best as she could. Her breath was running ragged and she felt light-headed, but her arms and legs pushed on. She was probably going to faint the moment she reached the tray, but as long as she could hold out until then...

The mage was just nearing the base of the scone when the Golden Deer was swathed in shadow. Lysithea, far too focused on staying alive at the moment, couldn’t turn to face whatever was causing it. “Wh-what’s going on?!”

Her remaining classmates slowly turned to face the source of the eclipse - a hand far larger than anything that they’d ever seen before hanging over them. Far above, the cold emotionless eyes of their colossal professor stared down.

“Oh, Goddess...” Lorenz muttered under their breath, taken aback by just how imposing their giant teacher truly was.

“Heeeey! Professor! Down heeeeeeere!” Hilda jumped up and down on the spot, waving their arms with all their heart.

The professor remained indifferent. Their eyes showed no reaction - not even the slightest hint of alarm or surprise.

Claude felt a cold chill run up their spine. “That’s not good...”

*


As Byleth reached over to pluck a scone for herself, her hand faltered as it neared her bounty. Her emerald-green could just about spot a few specks wriggling around at the base of the nearest scone. There was even one clinging to the surface of the scone itself, no doubt nibbling away at the sugary treat.

Byleth felt a flicker of frustration. She was certain that she had wiped the table spotless before setting up for her tea party, and yet bugs were still insistent on their invasions. She had hoped that the days growing colder would stave them away, but perhaps her baked treats were just too delectable for the foraging creatures to pass up. Nonetheless, she couldn’t have pests infesting the tea table, especially if they were going to crawl all over the dessert tray.

“P-Professor?” Marianne asked sheepishly, having just finished another one of the baked treats herself. “Is something the matter...?”

Byleth flexed their hand.
155122.title: Uninvited Guests

choices: Marianne realizes they're not ants. Byleth Divine Pulses to get them back.
Marianne wants to finish the last ant off herself.
1551222.content:
(Violence warning. Gore and stuff. Minor, minor spoilers for Lorenz and Leonie’s B support.)

“It’s nothing,” Byleth answered. “Just some ants.”

Marianne didn’t respond, instead taking a sip of her own drink. While she cared for most forms of life in nature, she felt rather indifferent to most insects, including ants. Sure, the Goddess had a role for them in the world, but it wasn’t something she particularly valued. Though, for some inexplicable reason, she was fascinated by the way Byleth decided to cast judgement on the puny pests.

The comment had sent the shrunken students into a panic. They were found, but they were logically mistaken for a group of insects. Lysithea hurried down, but still found a ways to go before she could safely let go. Meanwhile, the others hesitated, unsure of what to do.

“We’re not ants, Professor!” Hilda cried, panic settling in on her voice. “We’re your students, who you love so much!”

Her pleas went unheard as the massive tip of Byleth’s finger came crashing down, crushing the tiny pink haired girl immediately. Everyone jumped back at the suddenness of Hilda’s death. Arguably the most lively student in the house was now gone, reduced to a red smear stuck in the ridges of the massive professor’s fingerprint.

“Oh, Goddess!” Leonie gasped, tearing her eyes away at the gruesome sight of Hilda’s remains on the formerly spotless plate.

“There’s no way,” Claude said coldly, failing to comprehend the sudden reality that one of his closest friends was now gone. “Hilda? HILDA!”

He tried to rush in, only for his cape to pull him back. He turned to see Lorenz holding onto him. “Pull yourself together, Claude! She’ll do the same to us if we don’t retreat.”

Claude nodded, taking in a pained breath. “R-right.”

Before they could truly get their bearings, the shadow returned, this time heading straight towards poor Lysithea stranded on the cliff of sugar.

“Lysithea! Just let go!” Claude demanded, hoping to prevent another senseless death. “We’ll catch you!”

It was far too late as the tiny mage was caught between Byleth’s thumb and index finger. She didn’t even survive the lightest of pressure as she popped almost immediately. It didn’t help that she was basically ground into a pulp as the giantess rubbed her fingers together, mashing her with some crumbs she tore off the dessert.

Bits of flaky crust and mashed Lysithea rained down on those below, threatening to crush them flat if they remained still. The three took action, running away from the shadow of the giantess and looking for any kind of safe place to hide. Unfortunately, it seemed that the vengeful titan was determined to eliminate them, not content to just let them escape.

They rushed to the edge of the plate, hoping to hop down and take cover under the rim. The gap, while high, was survivable if they just landed the right way. Claude took the lead, landing on both feet and letting his momentum break into a roll. Lorenz followed suit, surviving the fall, but finding it incredibly painful on landing as he limped away.

Finally, Leonie jumped off, landing awkwardly on an already injured foot. She let out a yelp in pain as she collapsed to the ground. Lorenz quickly rushed to her, already knowing the cause of her sudden fall. He helped her up and draped her over his shoulder, throwing away any noble pretense as he was more concerned with helping a friend.

Then Byleth returned, stabbing her finger right on top of the pair and snuffing out their screams. The pad of her finger had crushed Leonie, while the tip of her fingernail cut right through Lorenz’ waist.

Ironic, Lorenz thought grimly. A noble life reduced to the death of a lowly ant.

Claude stood, mouth agape in horror as he seemed to be the last remaining survivor of the incident. He turned to Marianne, who seemed to be watching him from high above. Didn't she love animals? Why didn’t she put a stop to this? He shook those thoughts out of his head, deciding to run to her and hope he could get her attention rather than the Professor that looked intent on killing him too.

—

Marianne watched as Byleth exterminated the ants on the table. There was something odd about the way they acted. The way they hesitated before moving or stuck together or reacted to the events differently than just an animal instinct. The professor’s methods of eliminating them were strange as well.

Was she… having fun doing this?

Byleth dragged her finger across the table. The blood of her students blended in a little too well to the reddish tint of the tea table. The existence of blood would have been a giveaway if she really looked out for it. However, no red flags were raised other than the need to get rid of these pests ruining what was a perfectly good tea time.

The last remaining ant seemed to be making a break for it, heading towards Marianne at the other end of the table. Byleth leaned forward, extending her reach just far enough as she rested her chest up on the table.

——

Raphael and Ignatz screamed as the table came closer at an alarming rate. The professor’s leaning had spelled a quick death for the both of them as her massive (even at normal size) chest came down onto the tabletop. Raphael, despite his muscles and brute strength, crumpled under the weight of Byleth’s breasts. Ignatz also succumbed, becoming a splotch of red not too dissimilar to spilled paint.

Meanwhile, Byleth hung her finger over the last ant, completely unaware that she had just killed two more of her students without even thinking about it.

"Wait!" Marianne bellowed.
1551222.title: Pests Pulverized

choices: Feeling overprotective, Byleth takes the shrunken students with her.
Byleth doesn't trust herself, and leaves the students with Marianne.
Byleth hides them somewhere safe, but someone unaware endangers them later.
15512221.content:
(Author's note: Diving into some headcannon with Byleth's behavior here. I'd imagine having to frequently rewind time to prevent their students' deaths would do a number on their psyche, no matter how stone-faced they are in the game. Also, mild spoilers for Sothis's identity.)

As Byleth leaned over the last remaining ant, Marianne squinted to get a good look at it. Why was it moving towards her? And was it her imagination, or did it seem to be... waving?

"WAIT!" Marianne bellowed. Byleth awkwardly straddled the table, further smearing Raphael and Ignatz's remains as she looked to her student with concern.

"What is it, Marianne? Do you see more of them?"

"I... I don't think they're ants!" Marianne answered as she leaned in to get a closer look. She gasped as Claude's form finally became recognizable to her. "P-professor! They're... they're..."

Feeling a mounting sense of dread from Marianne's behavior, Byleth put her finger down to the side and took a good look at the insect she was about to crush. Her eyes widened as she saw Claude, waving frantically to her with a look of sheer terror and despair on his face.

He was covered in blood.

"No..." Byleth breathed as she slumped back into the chair. She looked down and noticed a pair of red stains on her chest. She made the mistake of examining them closely, spotting what she was pretty sure was the mangled body of Raphael. "No, no, no..."

"Professor..." Marianne stared at Byleth in terror. "You... you killed them..."

Byleth stared at her trembling hand, soaked in the blood of her precious students. "NonononoNONO!"

Byleth collapsed, falling out of her chair as she lost consciousness.

---

Byleth awoke in a dark tomb. Across from her, sitting on a familiar throne, Sothis looked at her sadly.

"I... I killed them!" Byleth cried, collapsing onto her knees. "I killed them with my own hands!"

"You couldn't have known," Sothis said gently, approaching Byleth and embracing her in a hug. "I was there in your mind, Byleth. I thought they were ants as well. This isn't your fault."

"S-send me back," Byleth pleaded to the amnesiac goddess. "Please... please send me back..."

"Of course," Sothis nodded. She may not have been willing to allow use of the Divine Pulse during Byleth's first disastrous tea party after she mispronounced Lysithea's name and awkwardly asked her about boys in the monastery, but she would certainly let Byleth rewind time for this. "I'll send you to just before Marianne arrived. They should all still be alive then."

Byleth nodded. "Thank you, Sothis," she said with a shaky breath.

"We need to figure out how they came to be so reduced and on your tea table," Sothis said, returning to her chair with a contemplative pose. "Whoever did this to them clearly placed them there with this exact outcome in mind."

"The monastery's been compromised," Byleth mused, thinking of Tomas and Jeritza and their betrayals earlier that year.

"You must be careful of who you trust," Sothis agreed. "For now, go back to the start of the tea party. Your students need you."

---

"The food's not giant!" Ignatz yelled. "We're..."

Ignatz was cut off as a loud boom echoed behind Claude. The other three looked up and began backing away with varying levels of fear. Swallowing nervously, Claude turned around, only to see a very familiar amulet surrounded by two of the largest breasts he had ever seen. He craned his neck up, and his jaw drop in shock as he took in the impossibly giant visage of Professor Byleth.

Her expressionless face framed by long green hair was visible in more detail than Claude had ever seen before. Her eyes were focused on the teacup next to them as she poured from an equally giant teapot, the normally quiet sound of the tea meeting the cup echoing like an oppressive waterfall.

"Teach!" Claude snapped out of his stupor and called up to her. "Hey! TEACH!"

"Don't bother," Ignatz sighed. "We all yelled to her when she was setting up the table. We're way too small for her to hear us."

As if to immediately prove Ignatz wrong, Byleth suddenly gasped in shock as she dropped the teapot, which shattered loudly on the floor below. She began to scan the table, her eyes sweeping over it methodically until she spotted four tiny specks near her teacup.

"Claude? Boys? Is that you?"

"Hey, Teach!" Claude waved casually. "Glad you found us so quickly. Little help here?"

Byleth smiled, barely blinking back tears as she nodded. "Where are the girls?"

"PROFESSOR! OVER HERE!"

Now that Byleth was actively listening for it, she could hear the tiny cries of her students from the direction of the dessert tray.

"Stay there," she ordered the tiny boys as she carefully got up and approached the tower of scones. Almost immediately, she spotted Hilda, Leonie, and Lysithea waving to her. Byleth reached for them before wincing and jerking her hand back, remembering the sight of her students' blood on it. Looking around, she saw a clean stirring spoon and brought that to them instead.

"Climb on, girls," she instructed, holding the spoon as steady as possible as she watched the trio board it, with Hilda and Leonie holding each of Lysithea's hands to ease the younger girl's fear of heights.

"Professor?" Byleth looked up to see Marianne enter the room, taking in her teacher's odd behavior and the broken teapot on the floor and frowning in concern. "Is everything alright?"

---

Claude barely restrained himself from throwing up. Glancing at the other six shrunken students, he could tell they were similarly afflicted. Apparently, having Physic cast on you when you weren't actually injured was a nauseating experience- like the magical or spiritual equivalent of eating too much.

The most annoying thing was that there WAS something wrong with him and his friends, and Physic was doing nothing to fix it.

"Again," Byleth ordered.

"Please no..." Claude muttered. This plea went unheard by the two giantesses up above as Marianne once more cast Physic on her shunken classmates in the vain hope of growing them back. This was too much for Hilda, who finally threw up off the side of the desk they were sitting on.

"I don't think it's working, Professor," Marianne said apologetically as she slumped onto an empty seat in the empty classroom they had relocated to. "I'm sorry. It must be my fault. If I were only a better healer..."

"No, Marianne," Byleth shook her head, immediately stopping her emotionally fragile student from blaming herself. "Whatever's happened to them must be too advanced for normal Faith magic to counteract."

"Perhaps we should consult Professor Manuela and Hanneman," Lorenz suggested. "Or perhaps even bring the matter to the Knights of Seiros or Seteth and Lady Rhea?"

You must be careful of who you trust, Sothis's warning echoed in Byleth's mind. "No. We don't know who hasn't also been compromised like Tomas. And if the last thing Claude remembers is trying to search for forbidden relic information in the library, we can't rule out Seteth either."

"What about Captain Jeralt?" Leonie immediately suggested.

"We can probably trust my father," Byleth agreed. "But he's away on a mission for the rest of the month. Remember?"

Ignatz suddenly shot up as the mention of Seteth reminded him of something. "What about Flayn? We still need to find out if she's shrunk too!"

Byleth frowned. Once the seven tiny Golden Deer were secure and out of the way, she and Marianne had searched every inch of the tea table trying to find the young green haired girl that had transferred to their house midway through the year. That they'd found nothing hopefully meant that Flayn was safe and normal sized somewhere in the monastery, but the idea of her being mistaken for an insect and killed just as Byleth had done to her students filled the concerned professor with dread.

"We should look for her while we investigate," Byleth agreed. "Marianne, let's split up and search the monastery. If you find Flayn, no matter what size she is, bring her here."

Marianne swallowed. As daunting as searching the monastery by herself was, her friends were counting on her. "A...alright."

"What about us?" Claude spoke up. Byleth looked at her shrunken students. The guilt she felt for killing them earlier was weighing heavily on her. On the one hand, she felt they were safest as far from her as possible. On the other hand, she didn't want to let them out of her sight for fear of accidentally harming them again.

"Professor?" Marianne's voice brought Byleth back to reality.
15512221.title: Fixing Mistakes

choices: Shamir and Catherine, who wanted to discuss something with Byleth.
A normal sized Flayn, who wants to know where her new friends have gone.
155122213.content:
Byleth came to a decision. She couldn't easily carry her shrunken students in such a way that wouldn't be dangerous, and she needed to search the monastery for clues and possibly a shrunken Flayn. Finding Flayn was important enough that Marianne, as the only normal sized person she knew she could trust, needed to search too, and her uniform didn't have pockets. The choice, therefore, was obvious.

"Marianne, can you carry your classmates to my room?" Byleth asked. "I'll give you the key."

"Um... of course, Professor," Marianne nodded. "But... wouldn't it make more sense for you to do it?"

If I hold them in my hands, it will make me think of seeing their blood on them.

"Professor?"

"I'd prefer to start the search for Flayn as soon as possible," Byleth came up with an excuse on the fly. "Once you drop them off, can you search around the fishing pond? I see her there on occasion. I'll check near the library and Seteth and Lady Rhea's quarters."

"Yes, Professor," Marianne lowered her hands to the desk so the shrunken Golden Deer could climb on.

"Oh, and Marianne? I hope I'm wrong and that Flayn was just somehow missed like you were, but in case I'm not... watch your step."

---

For as nervous as Marianne was, her hands were gentle and steady, calling upon a life's experience of dealing with birds and other skittish animals. In what was a surprisingly short and uneventful trip- save for having to take the long way to avoid Shamir and Catherine, who were having an unusually animated conversation in the courtyard- she brought her shrunken friends to the professor's room and placed them carefully on the desk.

"Are you all alright?" Marianne asked. "Can I get any of you anything before I go?"

"I could go for some food!" Raphael answered immediately.

Leonie groaned in exasperation. "Seriously?! Is that all you ever..." She was cut off as her stomach loudly growled. "Huh... okay, I guess it's been a while since any of us have eaten."

"The professor and I never finished our tea party," Marianne recalled. "It would be a shame to let those snacks go to waste. Hold on, I'll be right back." With that, Marianne quickly left. The sound of her closing and locking the door echoed throughout the cavernous room.

"Well," Claude sighed with relief. "At least we're safe now."

"But who could have done this to us?" Ignatz wondered. "Was it the Flame Emperor? Could they really be here in the monastery?"

"After Tomas... or Solon, I guess, did what he did, anything's possible," Claude shrugged. "Honestly, I'm more concerned about..."

Claude was cut off as Marianne returned with a plate of cookies from her ill-fated tea time with Byleth.

"Here we are," Marianne gingerly set them on the desk next to her friends. "I promise I'll get you something healthier from the dining hall later, but these should at least tide you over."

"You have our thanks, Marianne," Lorenz bowed. "But... were you not supposed to search for Flayn?"

"Oh my goodness!" Marianne gasped. Fearful that a delay on her part could lead to the possibly shrunken girl's demise, Marianne bolted from the room, not thinking to lock the door behind her this time as she slammed it hard enough to create a small quake.

Lysithea eyed the giant dessert tray before her. "If any of you tell the Professor about what I'm about to do, I'm using you for spell practice."

"Go ahead, Lysithea," Hilda nodded. "We know you want to."

With a shout somewhere between a cheer and a war cry, Lysithea charged for the nearest cookie, intending to devour as much of the giant sweet as possible. Raphael, never one to turn down food of any kind, was close behind her. As the rest of the class began to eat at a more sedate pace, Hilda approached Claude.

"What's up, Claude? You've got that 'thinking about a mystery too hard for your own good' look again. Still thinking about who might've shrunk us?"

"Well, yeah," Claude nodded. "But at this point, I'm worried more about Teach. Did she seem... off... to you?"

"How so?" Hilda tilted her head.

"It's subtle, but she seems kinda freaked out about this," Claude said.

"Well, look at us," Hilda gestured towards the two of them. "This isn't something that happens all the time, Claude."

"Yeah, but when Miklan turned into a giant monster, she didn't even bat an eye," Claude countered. "But something about this has her so freaked out, she doesn't even want to touch us. Like when she used that spoon to get you and the other girls off the cookie, or how she had Marianne take us here instead of doing it herself."

"That is odd," Hilda agreed. "What do you think it means?"

Their conversation was cut short by a booming series of knocks on the door.

"Professor?" a woman's voice called out.

"Pretend we're not here!" Claude quipped.

Leonie frowned as she looked up from the cookie. "Wait... is that...?"

An ominous creak silenced the shrunken students as the door slowly opened. The giantess on the other end was visibly just as surprised by the door opening as they were.

"Marianne forgot to lock the door!" Hilda shouted as yet another normal sized person, unaware of their plight and all the more dangerous because of it, set foot in the room...
155122213.title: In Which Marianne is Lax with Security

choices: Monica spots the whole class on the desk.
Monica spots Lysithea on the plate.
Monica doesn't spot anyone, but the Golden Deers still need an escape plan.
1551222133.content:
(Spoilers for Chapter 9 and 10.)

*


Monica hummed a cheerful little tune to herself as she skipped over to Professor Byleth's room. It had been long enough now that the other students had stopped needling her with pointless queries about if she was 'really okay' or 'putting on a face.' Oh, if only they knew, she thought to herself. Now she was free to go about her business, and if anyone asked, she was merely looking for the professor to assist her with some stubborn spellcasting problems of hers.

That was Monica's plan. Kronya's plan was quite different - she just wanted to check the likely places where a few pests might be hiding now.

The 'relic' she had planted in the library had worked like a treat, easily falling into the hands of that insufferable 'Claude' creature and the whelps that crowded around him all the time. She did wonder why Solon hadn't opted for something more immediately lethal against those who had interfered with his work in Remire, but if it could have meant a far more despair-inducing end at the fingertips of their own beloved professor, then Kronya was more than happy to oblige. It made her all the more furious that such a satisfying end of the story had slipped away. She had tracked down the table where Professor Byleth usually held their tea parties, only to find it woefully bereft of tiny red stains.

Fortunately, this was an error she could now correct herself. After checking the other tables and the dining hall, she had surmised that the professor might have discovered them and taken them to their room for safekeeping. Kronya could feel a tingle in her spine as she skipped closer and closer, imagining all the weird and wonderful ways she could dispose of these interlopers. Perhaps I'll pick them off one by one? She wondered, already making a murderous flowchart in her head to maximize the misfortune she could sow.

Before long, Monica stood before the hardwood door of the teacher's room. "Professor?" She knocked upon the door, and was pleasantly surprised to see it swing forward in response. They didn't even lock their room? This is just pathetic. She poked her head to the seemingly vacant room, remaining in character just in case. "I, uh, was having some trouble with my spells, I was wondering if you could help me...?"

With no response, the girl stepped into the room, and her murky red eyes began to skim around for her prize.

*


The giant Monica entered the room, leaving the Golden Deers in awe at another impossibly large figure looming in the 'distance.' Claude watched intently as the enormous student scanned her head around in apparent confusion as to where the professor may have gone.

"Ah, thank goodness, it's just Monica," Ignatz said, thankful that it wasn't a far clumsier individual.

Lorenz cleared his throat. "We'll be in danger if she remains unaware. We should do our utmost to get their attention."

"Hey, yeah!" Hilda agreed. Hilda began to inhale as much as she could with her surprisingly powerful lungs, but just before she could shout out in the hopes of grabbing the giant's attention, a hand swiftly slapped itself over her open mouth. It was Claude's.

"Everyone, behind the books now!" The house leader dragged a protesting Hilda along with him behind the books to evade Monica's line of sight. The students who heard quickly followed suit (despite their confusion) and fled from the plate to the 'cover' of the stacked books.

"What's gotten into you?" Leonie asked, eager for an explanation as Hilda wrestled herself free and stuck her tongue out at Claude.

Claude peeked his head around the 'tower' and kept his eyes locked on Monica as she pivoted hers around the room. He had always found Monica more than a tad suspicious. He was no stranger in insincere smiles, and she had recovered from her kidnapping a little too quickly for his liking. However, it was more than that now. "Doesn't anyone find it odd that Monica is looking for Teach when they're not even in our house? And on a day like today? Doesn't that seem like too much of a coincidence?"

Lorenz scratched his nose. "I... I suppose that's not the norm, but it hardly explains your rash behavior. It's very unbecoming of a noble to act this way, you know."

"Then tell me why they're looking around on the surfaces instead of just leaving. They can plainly see that Teach isn't here, so what else could they be looking for?"

Hilda furrowed her brow in a very Claude-like manner. "...Us?"

"Bingo," Claude continued. "And how do you think they could know about us?"

A grim realization fell upon the students. It wasn't definitive proof, but it raised a lot of unsettling questions, and now they could understand why Claude was erring on the side of caution.

"Yeah, so let's just sit this one out. We'll wait till she leaves, tell Teach about it, and-"

Claude did a quick head count... and felt his blood run cold. They were one man short.

*


Lysithea grunted with pain as she tried to wretch her leg free from the gooey chocolate chip puddle it had been submerged in by one misplaced step. The sweet sticky 'quicksand' kept her limb glued in place.

Great! Lysithea thought to herself. How could this day get any worse?!
1551222133.title: Not the Savior We Were Hoping For

15512222.content:
"Wait!" Marianne bellowed.

The sound her voice was more than enough to stop Byleth in her tracks as her finger hung dangerously over leader of the Golden Deer house. Even Claude was more or less frozen in place at the rare sound of Marianne raising her voice.

"Is there something the matter?" Byleth asked back.

In this moment Claude began to feel relieved. Marianne had just saved him from a similar fate as the rest of the Golden Deer. All he had to do was get their attention and quite possibly some help.

He didn't know what he'd tell the professor and Marianne about the rest of their class. He hadn't known the teach long, but he knew despite her lack of emotional response she cared a great deal about all of them. If she found out she'd snuffed them all out common insects then it would destroy her.

Marianne was very much the same.

Said girl began to grow slightly nervous at the revelation that she'd actually raised her voice. "I-I think that maybe,,, I should get this one."

Professor Byleth's face remained blank while Claude's eyes widened in terror. Did she just say she should be the one to kill him? "I thought she loved animals!"

"I thought you loved animals..." Byleth began. "Although, I guess that doesn't extend to insects."

Marianne shook her head. "It's not that I hate insects, I just don't particularly care for them."

"I think I understand." Byleth replied before moving her finger away. "He's all yours."

"No. No." Claude whispered as he began to back away. These two were never going to recognize him, instead they were going to turn him into a nondescript stain. "Teach?! Marianne?!"

His voice never reached them, the size barrier was too great. Had he been loud enough he might've been able to save everyone. Now he was all alone about to meet the same grizzly end. Not on the battlefield like a warrior, but as an ant in his own backyard.

His feet felt like cement as the tip of Marianne's finger was now the one looming over him. Unbeknownst to him or the professor she'd never actually smashed a bug before, at least not on purpose. She'd always either shied away or found some other means of scooping them up, but this was the first time she was willing going to snuff one out. As bizarre as it was, watching the professor crush pests with her finger was fascinating.

Just the simple act of bringing her finger down spelled doom for the bug that otherwise ruined a good tea party.

A punishment befitting the crime...

Marianne brought her finger down... and Claude was no more.
15512222.title: Pests Neutralized
